aboutTheApp.description:
Welcome to the travel app that you have all been waiting for!

This is not one that is powered by clever AI algorithms. Nor is it one were users are permitted to upload hundreds of fake reviews.

The content for this app is provided entirely by our dedicated team of professional travel writers and reviewers.

The only thing that matters to us is you, the user. We want you to be able to trust what you read here. If an attraction falls below expectations, then we will be honest and say so. If a restaurant is not up to scratch, then we won’t include it.

Fake reviews cause a huge problem for both consumers and honest businesses. Consumers waste money on poor experiences. Honest businesses struggle against competitors who bolster their image with unfair coverage.

Yet most travel apps out there allow just this: misleading reviews that harm consumers and distort fair competition.

All of our content is 100% independent. Our researchers have visited every single place that we include within this app, often multiple times. We do not take any payment for favourable coverage.

All adverts are totally separate from editorial content. We will always indicate where content has been sponsored.

We want to be different. We believe that you want us to be too.

kaelderkold.address: Carrer del Cardenal Casañas, 7, Ciutat Vella, 08002 Barcelona, Spain
kaelderkold.description:
If you are a fan of craft beer, this is a good place to try for the range of beers on tap and for its welcoming and convivial atmosphere.

The bar staff are knowledgeable about the beers that they serve. As is usual with these kinds of places, you can sample the beer before you commit to a full pint.

The bar also offers a tasting selection – five small pours for €15. Besides beers, the bar offers cocktails, wine and tapas-style snacks. Non-alcoholic beer is available, too.

The beers being sold changes frequently. Many of them are Spanish, but there are some foreign imports as well.

There are two parts to the bar. The upstairs part, close to the bar, is fairly small, with most of the seating running alongside the serving counter. There is also another room downstairs.

The vibe might best be described as rocky hipster. Classic rock tracks play in the background.
kaelderkold.name: Kælderkold

motelOneBarcelona.address: Pg. de Pujades, 11-13, Sant Martí, 08018 Barcelona, Spain
motelOneBarcelona.description: Across from sprawling Parc de la Ciutadella, this modern hotel on a tree-lined thoroughfare is a 5-minute walk from the nearest metro station .
motelOneBarcelona.name: Motel One Barcelona

aventuricoMonumentalBarcelona.address: Carrer de la Diputació, 455, L'Eixample, 08013 Barcelona, Spain
aventuricoMonumentalBarcelona.description: The floor is lava turned into an exilirating game thanks to technology. Tiles are changing colors under you feet testing your reflexes while challenging your logic and team spirit. A great adventure escape to enjoy with friends.
aventuricoMonumentalBarcelona.name: Aventurico Monumental Barcelona
aventuricoMonumentalBarcelona.openingHours: Wed - Fri: 2pm to 12am, Sat & Sun: 9am to 12am

checkpointArcade.address: Carrer de Bailèn, 43, bajos 2, Eixample, 08010 Barcelona, Spain
checkpointArcade.description: Amazing bar with a wide range of classic and modern videos games, it also boats a decent selection of board games and beers.
checkpointArcade.name: Checkpoint Arcade
checkpointArcade.openingHours: Tue-Thu: 6pm to 12am, Fri-Sat: 6pm to 2am, Sun: 10am to 7pm

makeIt.address: Carrer de la Indústria, 186, L'Eixample, 08025 Barcelona, Spain
makeIt.description: Whether you're an artist or a beginner, painting ceramics is a blast and surprisingly relaxing. After painting, you’ll leave your piece to be glaze-fired, a process that transforms dull colors into vibrant, glossy finishes, elevating your creation into a stunning, living room shelf-worthy masterpiece.
makeIt.name: Make it

virtuaVirtualRealityArcade.address: Carrer de Viladomat, 95, L'Eixample, 08015 Barcelona, Spain
virtuaVirtualRealityArcade.description: Virtua offers virtual reality technology that allows you to have immersive experiences—from exciting journeys through unknown galaxies battling aliens or surviving zombie apocalypses, to peaceful walks through virtual natural landscapes.
virtuaVirtualRealityArcade.name: Virtua Barcelona

cavaWineries.description:
Most producers of Spanish cava are located in the El Penedès region of Catalonia, which is about a 45-minute drive northwest of Barcelona. There are only a few cava wineries located elsewhere in Spain, so this is really the best place to come if you want to find out more about the history and tradition of Spain’s sparkling wine.

**Getting there**

Getting to the wineries is easy if you have car – although of course, if you do decide to drive yourself, you will then be limited to the amount of wine-tasting you can do .

An alternative way of exploring the region is to hire a car with a driver, although this is likely to be a more expensive option. You should mention what wineries you want to visit, and expected waiting time at each one, before you set off in order to negotiate a convenient price.

You can also take a train from Placa Catalunya to some cava wineries. The most popular station is Sant Sadurní d'Anoia train station, which is a short walk or a taxi ride to many of the wineries.

The final option is to join an organised tour. Several companies in Barcelona organise these. The Penedès Tourist Board provides details of tours that are available. It also offers advice of what else there is to do in the region, besides just sampling the local wine.

**Why go?**

El Penedès is a picturesque area, with plenty of quaint towns that you can drive through or stop at. There are also some nice walks to be had here as well.

Not all wineries in the region are open to the public, but it is not difficult to find those that do welcome visitors. They will usually have details of visiting times on their website, as well as any particular tours that they offer.

Some of the popular wineries that you can visit in the region are Cordoniu, Freixenet, Recaredo, Vilarnau, Alta Alella, Llopart, Gramona, Castellroig. Check their websites for the latest details.

**Eating options**

There are plenty of local eating options in the towns and villages that are spread throughout the region.

A number of the wineries also offer some food along with the wine tasting - check their websites for details..

Typical food from the region includes *Gall del Penedès* (rooster), *coques enramades* (flatbreads) and an endive salad served with cod, tuna, anchovies and a romanesco-style sauce known as *xató*.
cavaWineries.name: Cava Wineries

garrotxa.description:
A hundred or so kilometres northwest of Barcelona, you will find a collection of distinctive volcanoes (about 40 of them), a great location for hiking and horse-riding.

**Getting there**

You really need a car if you are going to explore this area properly. The journey into the region will take around 90 minutes, depending on traffic.

It is also possible to take a bus from the centre of Barcelona to Olot, the capital of the region. The bus leaves from near Plaça Catalunya, and the journey takes just over two hours. There are then some local buses that you can catch between towns.

**Why go?**

One of the reasons that so many tourists come to this area is the spectacular hikes that it has to offer.

It is also very good horse riding country, and there are plenty of equestrian centres that offer trips around the national park.

You can also explore the area by bike - or even hot air balloon!

You will find some very well-preserved medieval villages here, with old bridges, churches, mills and castle ruins. Besalú is probably the most famous. It is very pretty, although it can get a little crowded during the summer months.

**Other villages worth visiting are Santa Pau, Sant Joan les Fonts and Sant Feliu de Pallerols. All of these have tourist information centres in them.**

**Eating options**

It is not difficult to find decent restaurants in the national park.

You will find many of these along the walking trails that thread through the region, great for stopping off at the end of a vigorous day’s hike.

Make sure you plan ahead, though. During the peak season you will almost certainly have to book ahead, possibly days in advance.

A traditional type of pasteurised goat’s cheese, known as Garrotxa cheese, is popular in the region.
garrotxa.name: Garrotxa Volcanic Park

montserrat.description:
Montserrat is a mountain range to the north of Barcelona, most famous for Benedictine monastery there. Montserrat literally means ‘serrated mountain’ – a tribute to the distinctive jagged peaks that can be seen as you approach.

**Getting there**

The Monastery of Montserrat is about an hour’s drive away from the centre of Barcelona.

There are no tolls along the way, but be warned that the roads can get exceeding busy during weekends and on public holidays, especially if the weather is fine.

If you don’t arrive by 10am on such days, then you are likely to queue before you are allowed to enter the parking area.

Car parking is not free. Expect to pay around €7 for the day if you have a small car (the price increases with the size of your vehicle). There are a few charge points for electric vehicles at the site.

Another popular way of getting to Montserrat is by train. The R5 train runs regularly from Plaça España to the foot of Montserrat (the journey time is just over one hour). From there you can decide to either take the rack railway or the cable car up to the top.

You can buy a combined ticket that includes both the train journey and the journey to the top of the mountain.

**Why go?**

One of the reasons that Montserrat has become such a popular destination is the monastery of Santa Maria, which was originally founded in 1025. It was rebuilt in the 19th and 20th century, and is still actively used by around 70 monks.

This was one of the most important starting points for pilgrims who wanted to walk the Camino de Santiago, a 1000-mile route to another monastery in the west of the country.

One of the most famous artefacts within the monastery is that of the Black Madonna, which is believed to have been carved in Jerusalem at the beginning of Christianity. Black Madonnas can be found all over the world. This is one of the most famous.

**Eating options**

There isn’t a great deal of choice about where to eat at the monastery, so you may want to bring your own packed lunch.

During weekends there is usually an open air food market where you can buy local produce such as cheeses, olives and cold cuts. One traditional cheese that is widely sold in the market is mató de Montserrat, which has a similar texture to ricotta but with a milder taste. The cheese is often served with honey.

There is a large café at Montserrat, which serves reasonable coffee and decent sandwiches, plus other snacks and drinks. There is seating both inside and out. This is a nice place to relax, especially if you have just finished a hike.

Alternatively, if you drive down the mountain, you will find a few towns that have some small eateries.
montserrat.name: Montserrat

description: There are several options for travelling to and from Barcelona El Prat Airport, which is situated 12 kilometres southwest of the city center.

**Aerobus**

The Aerobus is a dedicated shuttle service that connects the airport terminals with key locations in the city center.

Bus A1 serves Terminal 1 while A2 serves Terminal 2. Both routes include stops at Plaça de Catalunya and Plaça de Espanya.

The journey to Plaça de Catalunya takes 30–35 minutes, depending on traffic conditions. Tickets can be purchased online, at ticket machines, or directly from the driver. You can pay in cash, but the driver may not always have the exact change to give you.

The buses run 24-hours a day, 365 days per year. They are comfortable and equipped with ample luggage storage. They also have free WiFi and USB charging plugs – although these plugs aren’t always working.

Be very vigilant about your luggage. Thieves frequently target tourists arriving in the city!

**Metro**

Metro Line 9 runs between the airport and the city centre. There are two routes. L9S1 terminates at Zona Universitària. L9S2 terminates at Can Tries - Gornal.

Both routes pass through Fira (where Barcelona’s trade fair exhibition), Collblanc (where you can change to Line L5) and Torrassa (where you can change to Line L1).

Each of the airport terminals has a metro station. If you arrive at T1, you'll find the metro station within the terminal building. If you arrive at T2, follow the signs to the metro station located just outside.

Regular metro tickets cannot be used to travel to and from the airport. You need to purchase a special airport ticket. You can do so online or directly from the machines at the metro station. Many (though not all) of these machines accept cash. They all accept major credit and debit cards.

**Renfe Train**

The R2 Nord line of the Renfe train network connects the airport to the city center. The train stops at major stations, including Sants Estació and Passeig de Gràcia. Trains are generally efficient and provide a direct route to the city.

The main benefit of using the Renfe train system is the cost. You can purchase a book of 10 tickets for €13. This works out as €1.30 per journey, and can take you anywhere on the public transport network.

Unfortunately, only Terminal 2 is served by this train. Therefore, if you arrive at Terminal 1, you may find it more convenient to take alternative transportation, such as the metro or Aerobus. However, there is a free shuttle bus that runs between the two terminals (every 5-10 minutes, apart from between 8pm and midnight when the buses run every hour).

Trains are not 24 hours. They run from 5.20am to 11pm. They are also not as frequent as other modes of transport, with trains leaving at 30 minute intervals.

**Taxi**

Taxis in Barcelona are equipped with meters that calculate fares based on distance travelled and time spent in the taxi. Rates are regulated by the city.

Rides between the city centre and the airport typically cost between €20 and €35. There is a fixed supplement from the airport of €4.30, on top of the regular meter cost. There are also some additional costs that you may incur. Ffor example, when travelling with larger groups or taking a taxi during certain public holidays.

Most taxis in Barcelona accept both cash and credit / debit cards for payment. However, it is a good idea to carry some cash on you in case card payment is not possible (or ask before you get in).

Tipping is optional, but it is fairly common to round up the fare or add a little extra for good service.

The most popular taxi-hailing app in Barcelona is Cabify. Free Now is also available. Uber is not currently operational in the city.

**Driving**

Parking fees at Barcelona’s airport are not as high as you might expect, which means that taking your car to the airport can be a very convenient option, especially if you are only going to be away for a few days.

If you reserve in advance, you can park right next to the terminal building for as little as €12 a day. It will be quite a bit more expensive if you don’t book in advance, however.

For shorter stays, the rates are also very convenient, and an hour’s parking should only cost a few euros.

Stays of 15 minutes or less are completely free at Express Parking. This is to allow drivers to drop passengers off or pick them up.
arrivingByPlane.name: Barcelona's Airport

description: Barcelona is generally a safe city for travellers, but petty crime (especially pickpocketing) is unfortunately fairly common, especially around tourist areas. Violent crime is rare. Tourists using a bit of common sense should be able to avoid this kind of trouble.

**Most common crimes in Barcelona**

Pickpocketing is particularly common in areas frequented by lots of tourists, such as Las Ramblas, Plaça de Catalunya, the main metro stations along the L1 and L3 lines, sightseeing hotspots and the beach in Barceloneta.

Bag snatching occasionally takes place from the terraces outside restaurants, from benches and at the beach.

Watch out for the many scams aimed at tourists, too. These include being offered a friendship bracelet (and then asked for payment once it has been tied on), fake petitions from those pretending to be charity workers (always check the ID), fake ticket touts and counterfeit goods (often sold in the open around Plaça de Catalunya).

Bike and scooter theft is also fairly common. Be careful where you leave them. Even locked ones can be easily stolen if left in more deserted areas where there are not a lot of people.

**Top safety tips**

Don’t hang bags on chairs or leave phones and wallets on tables.

Use a money belt or inside-pocket bag.

Be extra careful on the metro, especially when it’s crowded or someone tries to distract you.
Never leave belongings unattended at the beach.

At night, stay in groups in well-lit areas, especially in El Raval and the Gothic Quarter.

**Useful numbers**

The general emergency number for police, ambulance and the fire service is 112.

You can contact the local police directly on 092. This number should be used for non-emergency situations.

If you have lose something at the airport, you can call them at: 932 596 440.

For misplaced items on the bus or metro, you can call the public transport customer service hotline: 900 701 149.

For hospital treatment, try Hospital Clinic de Barcelona (932 275 400) or Hospital del Mar (932 483 000).
crimeAndSafety.name: Crime and safety

description:
Barcelona’s web of public transport consists of the metro, buses, a commuter line known as the Ferrocarril and a suburban railway service known as the Rodadilla.

Public transport operates from 5am to midnight in many areas during the week. On Fridays and the evenings before public holidays, service is extended until about 2am. On Saturdays the Ferrocarril and the metro run continuously throughout the night.

**Tickets**

Barcelona and the surrounding areas are considered to be in zone one. If you are travelling outside of the city, you may need to buy tickets that cover other zones as well. Only the Ferrocarril and Rodadilla travel to other zones.

A single ticket can only be used for one journey. If you are transferring from one mode of transport to another (for example, from the bus to the metro), then you will need to purchase a separate ticket-

When travelling by metro and bus, you only need to validate your ticket when you get on. For the Ferrocarril and Rodadilla you will also need to validate your ticket on exit as well, so that it is clear which zones you have travelled between.

Children under the age of four can travel free on all transport, including the metro, buses, trams, and trains.​

**T-Mobilitat**

You can buy single tickets for each journey that you take, but if you are planning on making several journeys, you should get hold of a T-Mobilitat travel card, onto which can be added various travel packages (see below)..

A standard T-Mobilitat travel card is available for a small fee at the vending machines that can be found at any metro station. You do not need any ID to purchase these cards.

You can also obtain a personalised travel card, which is handy in case you lose it. Personal travel cards are available from most T-Mobilitat offices. Some work by appointment, whereas at others you can just turn up. You will need to show your passport or photo ID in order to get a personal travel card.

**Available packages**

These are the packages that you can add to your travel card.

**T-Usual**. This is a monthly subscription package that offers unlimited journeys within the designated zone or zones. For a number of years this package has been offered at a 50% discount, which makes it extremely convenient. This is for personal use only; you need to enter the document number of your ID when purchasing it.

**T-casual**. This is a block of 10 tickets. Each ticket works out at around half the price that you would buy a single ticket for. The T-casual option is personal, meaning that you cannot share this between multiple users. Note that these tickets are not valid for travel to the airport.

**T-Familiar**. This is a multi-person travel card in Barcelona, ideal for groups or families. It provides eight journeys that must be used within 30 days of first use. Each journey allows up to three transfers within 75 minutes for one-zone trips, with an additional 15 minutes for each additional zone that is crossed. Again these tickets are not valid for travel to or from the airport. 

**T-jove**. This package is only available for young people under the age of 30. It offers unlimited travel within the selected fare zones for a 90-day period from the first use. To use it, you must have a registered T-Mobilitat profile. The card is non-transferable.

**T-16**. This option is only available for residents between the ages of four and 16. This allows unlimited free travel within a child’s zone of residence until six months after his or her 16th birthday. The card is free to obtain.
gettingAround.name: Getting Around

description: There are two official languages in Barcelona: Castellano and Catalan.

**Casetellano**

This is the official name for the language that most people now refer to as ‘Spanish’, spoken by nearly half a billion native speakers around the world, principally in Spain and in Latin America.

Only Chinese has more native speakers than Spanish. Spanish is the world’s fourth most spoken language overall, after English.

Spanish is a Romance language and shares similarities with Portuguese, Italian, French, and Romanian.

**Catalan**

Catalan is the historical language of the Catalonia region, and it is one that locals are very keen to protect.

If you want to endear yourself to the locals, try to learn at least a few words of this language. It will be very much appreciated.

You will also often hear Catalan spoken in public transport and at local shops. Teaching at local schools is generally in Catalan.

**English**

Barcelona is one of the most international cities in Spain, which means that you hear a lot of English being spoken.

The language is widely understood in hotels and in tourist areas, although the level of proficiency can vary a lot.

It is easy to find shows and other entertainment in English. Many cinemas show version original films, with subtitles in Castellano and Catalan.

There are also quite a few international schools where the teaching is mostly in English.
language.name: Language

description: The official currency of Spain is the euro (€).

**Paying by card**

It is very common to pay for things by card in Barcelona, even for small transactions such as when buying a coffee. American Express is less widely accepted than Visa and Mastercard. 

There are certain establishments that only accept cash, but these places will usually have a clear sign outside telling you this, before you enter. We have indicated in this app where places only accept cash.

**Withdrawing money**

ATMs are found all over Barcelona. However, many may have withdrawal fees if you are not a customer of the bank in question. Indeed, even if you have a Spanish bank account, you may be charged for taking money out at a different bank.

You can exchange money at many places in Barcelona, including currency exchange offices, hotels, airports, and travel agencies.

**Tipping**

Tipping for good service is appreciated in Barcelona, although not required.

For most restaurants, a tip of between 5% and 10% is considered reasonable.

In taxis, rounding the fare up to the nearest euro is common practice. If you have received good service, a 5-10% tip is again considered decent.
money.name: Money

description: For short stays, using international roaming may be the most convenient way of staying connected, but this can end up being costly (especially if your network provider is from a non-EU country). For longer stays - or to save a bit of money - you might want to think about a local option instead.

**Service providers**

The main telecoms providers in Spain are Movistar, Vodafone and Orange.

Movistar is the largest operator and generally has the best coverage across the country. Vodafone 

Cheaper options include Digi, Simyo, MásMóvil, Yoigo, Pepephone, Lebara and Lyca.

Some telecoms companies offer packages that include cheap (or even free) calls, so it can pay to shop around.

**Prepaid SIM cards**

Basic prepaid SIM cards typically cost between €10 and €20 and come with a small amount of credit. Many plans allow you to top up your credit and choose data bundles to suit your needs.

You will need to provide your passport or some form of photo identification in order to purchase a SIM card.

**Subscription plans**

If you're planning to stay in Barcelona for a long time, you might want to consider getting a long-term mobile contract. 

Some monthly subscription plans offer data only, while others include calls as well. Many plans offer free national and international calls to certain destinations.

You will need a Spanish bank account in order to arrange a long-term contract. You will also need to provide your passport or some form of photo identification.

The minimum duration of most contracts is between 12 and 24 months.
phonesAndTheInternet.name: Phones and the internet

description:
Barcelona is a sports-loving city, with **football** (soccer) being by far the most popular, thanks to its iconic FC Barcelona team. The team´s Camp Nou stadium is a major tourist attraction.

Other popular sports include **basketball**, **tennis**, **cycling** and a range of **beach sports** (beach volleyball, windsurfing, paddelboarding, etc).

**Motorsport**, particularly Formula 1, also has a strong following in the city.

**Padel** is a popular racket sport in Spain, often described as a mix between tennis and squash. It is played on an enclosed court about a third of the size of a tennis court, and is typically played in doubles. The sport is easy to pick up, making it accessible to all ages and skill levels. There are numerous padel clubs and courts across the city. It will not be difficult to find one that you can play at.
sport.name: Sport

description: Large supermarkets are usually open until at least 9pm, Monday through Saturday. They are generally closed on Sundays, although you may find a few that are open on Sunday mornings. Note that the ‘supermercat’ shops you see around town are little more than grocery stores, often selling basic products at highly-inflated prices.

**Mercadona**

These stores are generally fairly large. They sell a lot of ready-to-eat meals. The Spanish tortillas and croquettes are not bad.

Most outlets have a small kitchen area with a microwave where you can heat up any meal that you have brought.

Mercadona stores tend to have a large meat section, along with a machine for slicing ham and other cold cuts. The chain is less strong on food and vegetables.

It is possible to order online and have home delivery, for a fee.

**Carrefour**

Expect to find a good amount of French produce in these stores.

In the centre of Barcelona, outlets tend to be fairly small, whereas on the city’s outskirts they can be really big and offer a great selection of products.

Online and in the big shops, Carrefour sells everything from food produce to mobile phones and car tools.

**Lidl**

This is a popular discounted supermarket chain.

Prices for many things are a lot more attractive than at other supermarkets. The supermarket also runs regular offers.

The quality is a bit lower than other supermarkets (it is difficult to find decent fruit and vegetable here, for example), but much of the produce is not bad for the price. Cheese is decent.

Most Lidl stores do not do deliveries, although there are some very rare exceptions (the branch in Santa Antoni, for instance).

The queues, especially in the centre of town, can often be quite long.

**Aldi**

This is another popular discount supermarket, with lower prices than most supermarkets (but also lower quality). This supermarket also does not do deliveries.

**Veritas**

This is a very good organic supermarket that offers high-quality products - with a price tag to match. Free delivery is available, providing that a certain amount is ordered. This minimum amount tends to be less than in other supermarkets.

**Ameteller**

This supermarket chain is great for fruit, vegetables, yoghurts and wholemeal bread. It also has a very good meat counter.

The fish is decent, too, but it only comes in sealed packages.

They do very good ready-to-eat sushi as well.

Prices are more expensive than at many other supermarkets, but the quality tends to be much higher.

You can order online and delivery is free above a certain amount.

**Dia**

This is an everyday supermarket. Prices are lower for a number of things, especially packaged produce. The quality for fish and other fresh produce is not the best. Home delivery is available.

**Bonpreu**

This is a good supermarket chain with a decent variety of products. They have a unique service: if you buy fresh fish here, they will cook it for you at no extra cost.

**Plusfresc**

This supermarket chain only has a few branches in Barcelona.

The quality is good, with a great fish and meat counter, and very decent fruit and vegetables. Prices aren’t the lowest, but the chain does have weekly offers.

They do home delivery - or you can arrange to pick your order up at the counter.

**Consum**

This supermarket chain has plenty of foreign products in addition to local ones. It has good prices but not many offers. Many outlets have a fish counter although the variety and quality may not be quite as good as the more expensive supermarkets.

**Caprabo**

This is one of the main supermarkets in Barcelona, convenient for weekly shopping on a budget.

The chain has an attractive rewards programme, where if you shop at the supermarket regularly you receive 2% back at the end of the month, which can be used for future Caprabo purchases.

The meat is reasonable, but vegetables are not the best. Some outlets have a meat and cheese counter, but not many of them.

Capbrabo delivers for free for orders above a certain amount.
supermarkets.name: Supermarkets

description: Here are a few apps that you might find useful during your stay in Barcelona:

**CityMapper**

Great for finding you way around.

**Glovo**

Useful for ordering groceries and meals from supermarkets, and getting something small from one place to another in the city.

**Freenow**

This is the app for hailing official taxis in the city.

**Cabify**

This is the local equivalent of the ride-hailing company Uber (Uber is not currently allowed in Barcelona).

**T-Mobilitat**

Handy if you want to store your transport ticket on your phone rather than keeping a physical card with you all the time. This doesn’t work on iPhones for the time being.

**TheFork**

This allows you to make reservations, and get discounts, at many of Barcelona’s restaurants.

**Atrapalo**

With this app you can search for (and buy) tickets for a variety of shows in Barcelona.

**Playtomic**

Useful for finding a padel court or tennis court.
usefulApps.name: Useful Apps

description: EU citizens - plus those of the European Economic Area  EEA and Switzerland - can enter Spain with a valid national ID and stay indefinitely. Citizens of many other countries (including the US, Canada, the UK, Australia, and Japan) may not stay longer in Spain or any other EU country for longer than 90 days within any 180-day period.

**NIE**

A Foreigner Identification Number (known as a NIE) is vital for carrying out many legal and administrative tasks in the country, such as: working and paying taxes in Spain, buying or renting a property, opening a bank account, signing freelance contracts, enrolling in schools and universities and getting utilities connected.

If you are planning on staying in Barcelona for any length of time (rather than just visiting as a tourist), you really should try and get one. Unfortunately, while obtaining a NIE should be straightforward, it is extremely frustrating, largely because of the difficulty in obtaining an official appointment. Available appointment slots fill up extremely quickly, and sometimes there are none available at all for days and days.

Some unofficial agencies can help overcome this bureaucratic hurdles (for a fee!), but we cannot endorse this approach since it is not strictly-speaking legal. If you book an appointment in this way, there is no guarantee that you will be seen.

Obtaining the appointment is the hard part. Once this is done, the process should be relatively smooth, providing that you bring all everything with you to the meeting (all completed forms, identification and the receipt showing that you have paid the required fee online).

There are three types of residency certificates.

The *NIE Verde* (Green Nie) is only available for EU citizens. It confirms legal residence and allows full rights to live and work in Spain. While the Green NIE is the preferred document to have when taking up residency in the country, because of the bureaucratic hurdles described above, many choose to get the White NIE instead (see below) and may never get the chance to switch over to the Green NIE.

The *NIE Blanco* (White NIE) is does not grant residency rights, but it does allow you to carry out many of the administrative tasks that you might need to do, such as renting a property or opening a bank account. This is often granted to non-EU citizens with business or personal interests in Spain.

The TIE - Foreign Identity Card - is the equivalent of the Green NIE for non-EU citizens. To obtain it, you have to apply for it while in Spain with a valid residency visa.

It will make your life easier if you manage to get a NIE from outside Spain, which you can do so via a Spanish consulate or embassy in your home country. This will only allow you to obtain a White NIE, however. The process is generally more organised and less in demand than within Spain, but it can still take several weeks depending on the consulate’s workload. You will need to submit form EX-15, a valid passport, a letter explaining your reason for needing the NIE and the relevant fee.

**Digital Nomad Visa**

Spain offers a Digital Nomad Visa for those who wish to live in Spain while working remotely for non-Spanish companies.

To be eligible for the visa you must:

- Be employed by or have a contract with a non-Spanish company, or be a freelancer with clients outside Spain
- Earn at least €28,800 per year. The requirement is higher if you have a family to support.
- Hold a university degree or have at least three years of professional experience.
- Have a clean criminal record.
- Obtain private health insurance valid in Spain.

You can apply for this visa at a Spanish consulate within your home country. If you are already in Spain, you can lodge an application directly with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

This visa is valid for an initial period of one year. It can be extended up to 3 years, with the possibility of renewal.
visasAndEntryRequirements.name: Visas and entry requirements

barceloneta.description:
Consider this area if you want to be close to Barcelona’s beach. Here you will also find the old port (good for catching tourist boats that show you a bit of Barcelona from the water), the city’s aquarium and the cable car that whisks visitors up to Montjuic.

You will find plenty of nightlife spots here, too, such as Opium, Pacha, and Shôko. Lively music often takes place at the restaurants on the beach.
barceloneta.highlights: Barceloneta is a lively seaside neighborhood in Barcelona known for its beaches, seafood restaurants, and old fishing village charm
barceloneta.name: Barceloneta

eixample.description: Eixample is a large district with a well-deserved reputation for being one of the safest in Barcelona. It has plenty of wide streets with good lighting, a mix of residential and commercial neighbourhoods and quite a few tourist spots to visit. Eixample is well-known for its modernist architecture and several iconic landmarks, Sagrada Família probably being the most famous. Since the area is so large, how close you are to the centre and to tourist attractions depends a bit on where you stay. The closest metro stops to the centre are Urquinaona, Passeig deGracia, Universitat and Diagonal. Sagrada Familia, on the other hand, is at the other end of Eixample, and a good 30-minute walk from the old town area. The area is well connected with five metro lines (L1 through to L5) passing through it.
eixample.highlights:
One of Barcelona's safer areas, Luxury designer stores, Plenty of restaurants but quite touristy, 
Modernist architecture, Walking distance from key historical sites, Rent and hotels a bit on the pricey side, 
Popular for street events - 
means good proximity but also chaos
eixample.name: Eixample

subAreas.description: This is one of the most beautiful streets in Barcelona, full of iconic modernist buildings, such as Casa Batlló, Casa Amatller, Casa Lleó Morera and Casa Milà. There are plenty of luxury shopping spots in the area, too. This is a prime location in which meany visitors choose to stay, but it’s not the cheapest. You will find many luxury and boutique hotels here, all with correspondingly high price tags. The area is usually full of people. However, since the boulevard is fairly large, it doesn’t feel quite as crowded as the streets of the old town. Plaça de Catalunya (where the old town begins) is a seven-minute walk from here.  Five minutes away you will find the Egyptian Museum. This area lacks decent restaurants, supermarkets and cafés – but these you will find on some of the streets that run parallel. Many of the shops in this area are closed on Sundays, although the more luxury ones are likely to be open.
subAreas.name: Passeig de Gràcia (L2 - Purple Line; L3 - Green Line; L4 - Yellow Line)

subAreas.description: This area is a short walking distance from the city centre and many key tourist attractions, including some of Barcelona’s most famous modernist buildings and plenty of museums. The area has a range of hotels to match different budges, and there are plenty of restaurants and supermarkets nearby. The Airport Express passes through here, making travelling to and from the airport fairly convenient.  The area is a 25-minute walk from the beach.
subAreas.name: Urquinaona/Universitat (L1 - Red Line)

subAreas.description: This is a less touristic area than many other neighbourhoods in Eixample, with hotels and hostels that are generally more affordable. There are plenty of supermarkets and restaurants here. The area is close to the Sant Antoni food market and a 20-minute walk from Boqueria Market. Plaça d'Espanya is nearby.
subAreas.name: Urgell/Rocafort (L1 - Red Line)

subAreas.description: This is a more residential area. There are a few luxury hotels in the area, but most are in the medium price range. There are plenty of eating options here as well. Many of Barcelona’s main tourist attractions are not far away: Arc de Triomf (seven minutes), Parc de la Ciutadella (10 minutes), Barcelona Zoo (two minutes), Palau Macaya (five minutes), La Sagrada Família (15 minutes).
subAreas.name: Tetuán (L2 - Purple Line)

subAreas.description: This neighbourhood is a little further away from many of Eixample’s main tourist attractions (although only a 10-minute walk from Sagrada Familia). Hotel prices here are slightly cheaper than elsewhere in the district, and the purple metro line affords easy access to many of the main tourist attractions. The easiest tourist attraction to visit on foot is the former bullfighting ring, La Monumental, which is now used for concerts and events. It is famous for its Moorish-style architecture.  Avinguda Diagonal, a five-minute walk away, is a major avenue lined with shops, restaurants, and business centres. A 15-minute walk away is Glòries Tower, a futuristic skyscraper that lights up at night (although this isn’t really an area where you would want to stroll around at night!)  The Encants flea market is also 15 minutes’ away, as is the National Theater of Catalonia, which offers music concerts and cultural performances.
subAreas.name: Monumental (L2 - Purple Line)

subAreas.description: This is a fancy area full of luxury shopping centres, modernist architecture and lively plazas. As you might expect, accommodation here is not cheap. You will find several iconic buildings nearby such as Casa Milà – La Pedrera, Casa de les Punxes and Palau Robert. The area is also only 15-minute walk away from another much-loved part of Barcelona: Gracia.
subAreas.name: Diagonal (L3 - Green Line; L5 - Blue Line)

subAreas.description: This is a quiet yet central area, known for its modernist architecture, charming streets, and local cafés. You can reach many major landmarks in under 15 minutes, including Passeig de Gràcia, Sagrada Família, Parc de la Ciutadella and Arc de Triomf. There are plenty of decent restaurants in the neighbourhood. The area also has a fast metro link to the old town (enter it at the Jaume I metro station). There are good public transport connections to the various beaches of Barcelona, too (or you can walk to these in 20 minutes).
subAreas.name: Girona (L4 - Yellow Line)

subAreas.description: This is a bit outside of the main tourist area, but there are many beautiful art nouveau buildings nearby. Strolling through Carrer d'Enric Granados is a must! This historic Ninot food market is a five-minute walk away. This is great place for experiencing traditional Catalan cuisine. The modernist building Casa Sayrach is five minutes away, while Gaudí’s famous Casa Milà is less than 20 minutes away.
subAreas.name: Hospital Clínic (L5 - Blue Line)

subAreas.description: The main reason you might stay here, of course, is if you want to have Sagrada Família right on your doorstep. But there is also another modernist masterpiece that you shouldn’t miss: the former hospital of Sant Pau, which is a 10-minute walk away.
subAreas.name: Sagrada Família (L5 - Blue Line)

elBorn.description:
This is a great area in which to stay if you want to be in the historical part of the city, surrounded by beautiful churches, plenty of restaurants and cafés. The area is also in walking distance to the beach area of Barceloneta and the old port. Estación de Francia, the railway station that links Barcelona to parts of France, is also located here.

Much of the neighbourhood is pedestrianised. While this improves the safety of the streets, it also means that only official taxis are able to enter many of them. Neither Uber nor Cabify drivers are allowed.

The area is lively at all times, both day and night. Make sure you watch out for pickpockets, especially after sundown and in smaller darker alleys.
elBorn.name: El Born

subAreas.description: This area is located between El Born and the Gothic Quarter. This is a great location in which to be based since it affords easy access several beautiful areas of Barcelona on foot. This metro station is on a main road with both car and bus access.
subAreas.name: Jaume I (L4 - Yellow Line)

subAreas.description: This part of the neighbourhood gives easy access to Barceloneta Beach, which is a 10-minute walk away. It is also near the old port, where visitors can catch a boat to see a bit of Barcelona by sea. There are plenty of restaurants and cafés here (admittedly many of these are fairly touristy, though still might be pleasant for a drink). The smaller streets inside Barceloneta’s former fishing neighbourhood offer a more authentic experience of the city.
subAreas.name: Barceloneta (L4 - Yellow Line)

subAreas.description: Here you will find the zoo and Ciutadella Park, a pleasant place to go for a stroll. There is a lake in the middle with row boats for hire. The area is close to quite a few decent restaurants serving a variety of cuisines (Italian, Mexican, Spanish, Catalan). This is also where you will find Barcelona’s main Chinese neighborhood, good for Chinese food and supermarkets – and of course colourful celebrations during Chinese New Year!
subAreas.name: Arc de Triomf (Red Line - L1)

elRaval.description:
Raval is one of Barcelona’s most densely-populated areas. It has a very high immigrant population, and consequently still has a negative reputation among many locals.
Although not advisable if you are planning to come back late at night, it is becoming an increasingly popular area for those who want to stay close to the centre. More and more decent restaurants are springing up in the area, too.

Do exercise caution if you are going to stay in the area, though, and if you look like a tourist know that you could be an easy target, especially at night. Locals tend not to live here if they can avoid it so you will easily stand out. 

There are several points of interest nearby: the Museum of Contemporary Art, Palau Güell, Rambla del Raval, Sant Pau del Camp (a Romanesque church) and the Boqueria food market.
elRaval.highlights: El Raval is a vibrant, multicultural neighborhood in Barcelona known for its bohemian vibe, street art, and diverse food scene
elRaval.name: El Raval

gracia.description: Consider this area if you want to stay in a slightly less touristy area that has a bit more of a hipster vive – full of restaurants, cafés and cool wine bars. The area is still busy, but it feels more ‘local’ than the true city centre. Of course, it is a bit further away from the main tourist attractions, although direct buses connect to many of them. A popular summer street festival takes place here in August each year.
gracia.highlights: Gràcia is a charming, bohemian neighborhood in Barcelona known for its village-like feel, artistic vibe, and lively plazas
gracia.name: Gràcia

subAreas.description: Fontana is right in the heart of the neighbourhood. It’s only a four-minute walk away from Gaudí’s Casa Vincens. Although the area is 30 minutes from the Gothic Quarter and the attractions nearby, there is a direct metro line that runs there. Parc Guell is a 25-minute walk away.
subAreas.name: Fontana (Green Line - L3)

subAreas.description: This area is a five-minute walk from Casa Padua, and even less to that other modernist jewel Casa Ramos. This is one of the closest metro stations to Park Güell (a 15-minute walk).
subAreas.name: Lesseps – (Green Line – L3)

subAreas.description: Joanic is a well-loved area among locals, with spacious squares all around it, such as Plaça de la Virreina (a five-minute walk), Plaça del Sol (seven minutes) and Carrer de Verdi (10 minutes). This is where you will find the Verdi Cinema, which shows original-language films. This area is also the heart of Gràcia’s nightlife and social life, surrounded by trendy bars and restaurants. A great spot for evening drinks and tapas.
subAreas.name: Joanic – (Yellow Line – L4)

subAreas.description:
This is the area where Eixample and Gràcia intersect, making it a great starting point to explore modernist architecture, cultural sites, and charming neighbourhoods.

There are a number of attractions nearby, including the Gothic-inspired fairytale castle, Casa de les Punxes and Palau Macaya. Gaudí’s famous Casa Milà – La Pedrera is a 10-minute walk away while Sagrada Família is 15 minutes.
subAreas.name: Verdaguer (Blue Line - L5)

subAreas.description: This is a fancy area full of luxury shopping centres, modernist architecture and lively plazas. As you might expect, accommodation here is not cheap. You will several iconic buildings nearby such as Casa Milà – La Pedrera, Casa de les Punxes and Palau Robert. The area is also only 15-minute walk away from another much-love part of Barcelona: Gracia. As you might
subAreas.name: Diagonal (L3 - Green Line; L5 - Blue Line)

lesCorts.description:
This is principally a residential district, but it is become more and more known among tourists because of the number of large hotel chains that have set up here in recent years. Many of these hotels offer great facilities at a lower price when compared to similar hotels in the centre.

This is also a favourite area for the lovers of Barcelona Football Club because of the area’s proximity to the Camp Nou Stadium. This is a popular business district, too.

Although the area is a fair walk from the centre, there is a direct metro to the Gothic Quarter, which can whisk you there in under 15 minutes.

The area is still not too touristy and has a more local feel. Features include a high-end shopping mall (L’Illa Diagonal), Pedralbes Monastery and Reina Elisenda Gardens.
lesCorts.name: Les Corts

pobleSec.description: **Poble-sec** is a vibrant and up-and-coming neighborhood in Barcelona, known for its mix of local charm and lively nightlife. Nestled between **Montjuïc Hill** and **Avinguda del Paral·lel**, it offers a blend of historic theaters, trendy bars, and some of the best tapas streets in the city, like **Carrer de Blai**, famous for its pintxos. With its relaxed atmosphere, cultural venues, and proximity to green spaces, Poble-sec is a favorite for both locals and visitors looking for an authentic Barcelona experience.
pobleSec.highlights: Poble-sec is a lively yet laid-back neighborhood in Barcelona known for its theater scene, tapas bars, and Montjuïc access
pobleSec.name: Poble Sec

razzmatazz.address: Carrer dels Almogàvers, 122, Sant Martí, 08018 Barcelona, Spain
razzmatazz.description: Razzmatazz is a nightclub and concert hall in the Poblenou neighbourhood in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. It is one of the city's biggest with a capacity of over 2,000 people in its main hall.
razzmatazz.name: Sala Razzmatazz

reiDeCopes.address: Pl. Reial, 10, Ciutat Vella, 08002 Barcelona, Spain
reiDeCopes.description: Restaurant & bar by day, rei de copes turns into a reggeaton/popular hits club after 11PM. The entrance is free and there are two different rooms, a popular place amongts locals and tourists alike.
reiDeCopes.name: Rei de copes

Flauta.description: A flauta is a type of sandwich made with a thin, crispy baguette-style bread. The name comes from the sandwich’s elongated and slender shape, resembling a flute (or ‘flauta’ in Spanish). The sandwich is drizzled with olive oil and rubbed with tomato, before being filled with a variety of ingredients. Typical fillings include ham, cheese, salami and potato tortilla.
Flauta.name: Flauta

bikini.description: Don’t get confused! We’re not talking about swimwear here. In Catalunya, a bikini is actually a ham-and-cheese toasted sandwich. It is named after a nightclub that used to sell these tasty. The nightclub is still going, although the sandwiches are no longer sold there. These days it is possible to find bikinis in restaurants throughout Barcelona, although quite a few of these offer bikinis with other kinds of filling. This suggests that the definition of bikini may be changing, but for locals it is still the original ham-and-cheese toastie.
bikini.name: Bikini

bomba.description: A bomba is a ball of mashed potato filled with spicy ground meat, coated in breadcrumbs and lightly fried. It is typically served with a brava sauce (spicy tomato) and allioli (garlic mayo).
bomba.name: Bomba

botifara.description: A botifarra is a traditional pork sausage widely eaten across Catalonia. Botifarras tend to be thick and meaty. There are many different varieties, including black botifarra (botifara Negra) containing pigs blood and white botifarra (botifarra blanca) containing mostly lean meat. Raw botifarra (botifarra cruda) is the one you would typically cook on the barbecue.
botifara.name: Botifara

cafeConLeche.description: Café con leche (literally, ‘coffee with milk’) is the Spanish version of a cappuccino. It is a popular drink in Barcelona at any time of the day, The drink is made by combining strong coffee with steamed milk, in roughly equal parts. It tends to be less frothy than cappuccino.
cafeConLeche.name: Café con leche

calcot.description: A calçot is a type of green onion that is grown right across Catalonia. They are typically grilled on a barbecue and served from January to April. Calçots are traditionally dipped in a bowl of romesco sauce – a smoky Spanish accompaniment made with tomatoes and red peppers. Eating a calçot in the traditional way is certainly an experience, both for the one doing the eating and those who are watching. Start by peeling back the outer skin of the vegetable, use it to scoop up a generous amount of romesco sauce, throw your head back and then drop it into your mouth. Eating a calçot is as much about the theatre as it is about the taste. The best places to eat them are on the outskirts of the city or in the countryside, where they are cooked on an open barbecue with proper charcoal.
calcot.name: Calçot

cava.description: Cava is a Spanish sparkling wine made using the same fermentation process used to produce champagne. The overwhelming majority of cava (more than 95%) comes from Catalonia, although a few other cava producers are to be found in Aragón, Valencia, the Basque Country and a few other regions. Cava is generally more affordable that champagne.The grapes used in cava are not the same as that used in champagne, leading to softer and more floral notes than in the French variety. The Spanish white grapes of macabeo, parellada and xarel-lo are the ones most typically used in cava production.
cava.name: Cava

churros.description: Churros are the Spanish version of a doughnut – deep-fried strips of choux pastry, lightly sugared. However, they tend to be less dense and more crispy than doughnuts. They are often served with a rich and creamy mug of thick hot chocolate, into which they can be dipped. Churros may or may not come with a generous helping of whipped cream on the side. Good churros should not be overly sweet and may have a slightly salty tang, which goes perfectly with the hot chocolate. Churros are usually served warm and very good ones are dangerously moreish. They are very popular as an afternoon snack right across the region. To order ‘churros with hot chocolate and whipped cream on the side’, ask for ‘churros con chocolate y nata a parte’.
churros.name: Churros

hotChocolate.description: Hot chocolate in Barcelona is very distinctive: rich, thick and velvety. It has a consistency that is almost pudding-like, and may be quite different to the beverage you are familiar with back home. While the drink is rich and creamy, the flavours are not generally over-powering. Hot chocolate is a perfect accompaniment for churros, which are often dipped into it with great enthusiasm as an afternoon treat. If you want to indulge yourself and have whipped cream on the top, ask for  ‘un suizo’ (literally, ‘a swiss’). Despite the name, this is a typical Spanish way of drinking hot chocolate! To order hot chocolate (without the whipped cream), ask for ‘chocolate caliente’.
hotChocolate.name: Hot Chocolate

turron.description: Turron is a type of Spanish nougat typically made from honey, nuts and egg whites. It is traditionally eaten during Christmas and New Year. The confectionary, which is usually sold in specialist turron supermarkets or shops that are specialised in turrons, can be both chewy or crunchy. While turron isn’t originally from Catalonia, it is widely enjoyed throughout the region. These days you can find plenty of turrons that incorporate other ingredients, such as pistachios and pieces of fruit.
turron.name: Turrón

vermouth.description: Vermut - vermouth in English - is a fortified wine flavoured with herbs and spices. It is usually slightly bitter, although this depends on how it is produced. Catalan vermouth tends to be slightly sweeter than the vermouth served just over the border, in France. Vermouth is a big part of the culture in Catalonia, where ‘fer el vermut’ (literally, ‘do the vermouth’) often means gathering with friends or family before lunch. It is often enjoyed as an aperitif, typically accompanied by small platters of nibbles such as olives, anchovies or crisps. The area around Reus and Tarragona is particularly famous for producing Catalan vermouth.
vermouth.name: Vermouth

vichyCatalan.description: Vichy Catalan is Catalonia’s brand of sparkling mineral water. The water is sourced from the springs of Caldes de Malavella, northeast of Barcelona. The water is rich in minerals, particularly sodium bicarbonate, which gives it a slightly salty taste. The water is not to everyone’s taste, and is quite distinctive from the natural spring water that France and Italy are famous for. Nonetheless, it is very well known in the region and widely drunk by locals, who claim that it has many positive health benefits.
vichyCatalan.name: Vichy Catalan

event1.details: Palo Market blends design, fashion, gastronomy, and live music, offering a vibrant atmosphere. Expect artisan stalls, gourmet food trucks, and live performances in a beautifully restored industrial space.
event1.name: Palo Market: Design, Food, & Live Music in Poble Nou

event2.details: This Sunday, Passeig de Gracia turns into one giant open-air jazz club for Barcelona International Jazz Day. From midday to 10pm, catch six incredible live acts performing everything from classic jazz to modern fusion – all for free!
event2.name: Free All-Day Jazz Festival in Passeig de Gracia

event3.details:
On Saturday, over 70 horse-drawn carriages and 200 horses will parade through Barcelona for the Tres Tombs National Gathering. It’s a celebration of Catalan transport heritage, with marching riders, historic wagons (including Damm’s beer cart), and even a blessing of animals.

 Starts at Av. Reina Maria Cristina, goes through Eixample & Ciutat Vella
event3.name: Horse Parade in Eixample & Ciutat Vella

aquarium.address: del Port Vell, Moll d'Espanya, s/n, Ciutat Vella, 08039 Barcelona
aquarium.description:
Brochures describe this place as “the largest Mediterranean-themed aquarium in the world” (although there are fish from other parts of the world as well), and maybe this is the best way to think about it in terms of scale. The place certainly doesn’t feel particularly large, and it won’t take very long to see all it has to offer.

The star attraction is the huge tank full of sharks, stingrays and other marine animals. A nice feature is the moving walkway that visitors can stand on to be taken slowly around the giant (and underneath) the giant tank.

There aren’t all that many fish tanks leading up to this moment, though, and certainly the more exotic fishes are few and far between. The aquarium also has a small penguin enclosure.

There is a restaurant in the aquarium, but it’s not great. Think fast food and coffee in polystyrene cups.

All of this said, the place is a decent option for spending a couple of hours in Barcelona, and your impression of this aquarium is likely to be shaped by other aquariums you have already seen around the world. Kids are likely to enjoy it, and there is a small kids play area on the terrace just outside the restaurant.

The place can get fairly busy, especially in the afternoon and at weekends.
aquarium.name: Aquarium

archaeologyMuseumOfCatalonia.address: Passeig de Santa Madrona, 39, Sants-Montjuïc, 08038 Barcelona
archaeologyMuseumOfCatalonia.description:
This museum presents an overview of the ancient history of the Catalonian region, from early man up until medieval times, with a deep dive into the influence that the Roman Empire had here.

The explanations that accompany displays are interesting, but unfortunately the text is only in Spanish and Catalan – although an audio guide is available if you ask at reception.

There’s a nice virtual reality experience half-way through the museum, in which visitors can slip on a headset and find themselves transported to one of Catalonia’s most famous prehistoric burial caves, now a series of stones found near Romanyà de la Selva in the northeast of the region.

The museum is rarely busy.
archaeologyMuseumOfCatalonia.name: Archaeology Museum of Catalonia

arxiuFotographic.address: Plaça de Pons i Clerch, 2, 2n, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona
arxiuFotographic.description:
This is Barcelona’s official photography archive, offering a glimpse into the city’s rich history through the lens of a camera.

The collection contains thousands upon thousands of photographs that researchers are free to consult (with prior appointment).

The archive also organises regular exhibitions of some of its photos, based around particular themes, which are held in a small room adjoining the main archive. One of the most recent themes, for example, was entitled ‘Family, Friends and Photography’. Check the website for details of the current exhibition.

Photography enthusiasts are sure to get a lot out of this museum. If you just want to know about the history of Barcelona – without having to interpret it through the artistic beauty captured in these images – then there are other places to try.
arxiuFotographic.name: Photo Archive (Arxiu Fotogràphic)

barcelonaFootballClub.address: Carrer d'Arístides Maillol, s/n, Les Corts, 08028 Barcelona
barcelonaFootballClub.description:
You don’t have to be a die-hard football fan to enjoy a visit to Barcelona’s iconic Spotify Camp Nou stadium.

The museum is beautifully put together, really bringing to life the history of the club and the triumphs that it has enjoyed over the years. The accompanying audio guide significantly adds to the overall experience.

The first room displays club memorabilia from the past hundred years or so - fascinating to see how things have changed through the ages.

Subsequent rooms display various prizes and cups that the club has won, as well as a mosaic of football T-shirts (some are owned by the club, while others are on loan).

There is plenty of information about the current players at the club – both the men and the women – as well as a display dedicated to who may arguably be the most internationally renowned player to ever kick a ball around for the club: Lionel Messi.

Messi, who is an Argentinian footballer, joined the club in 2000, when he was just 13. He made his competitive debut when he was 17, and continued playing at Barça until 2021.

The museum has a giant auditorium where you can see members of the Barcelona squad, projected onto a giant screen that runs all around the room, passing a ball between themselves. Even if you are not an avid football fan, the atmosphere in this room is electric.

Outside, visitors can have a go at a penalty shootout against a robot goalkeeper (although this costs extra). This “robo keeper” is extremely tough to beat.

The entrance ticket to the museum also includes a visit to a “viewpoint”, where you can look at the ongoing construction of the new football stadium. Work began on the new and expanded stadium in 2022, and it is expected that the team will return to the stadium by the end of this year. The Barcelona team is currently playing home games at the Olympic Stadium in Montjuic.
barcelonaFootballClub.name: Barcelona Football Club

barcelonaHashMarihuanaAndHempMuseum.description:
This museum was set up in 2012 by Dutch businessman Ben Dronker, largely as part of a campaign to support the legalisation of cannabis (Richard Branson, the founder of Virgin, supported this campaign and also turned up at the inauguration). Weed is decriminalised for personal use in Barcelona, although it is still not fully legal.

Knowing the origin of the museum helps visitors appreciate how it has been curated. The museum still feels very campaign-like, extolling the virtues of the drug and ridiculing the prudish propaganda against legalisation, which has persisted through the decades.

Nonetheless, the museum is very interesting to visit, with plenty of snippets of information to pick up along the way. 

The museum also holds regular temporary exhibitions on the ground floor which are free of charge.

Just as fascinating as the museum is the magnificent building in which it is housed. As you wander around the museum, make sure that you take in the high ceilings with their fine decorations, the elaborate staircases, the intricate ironwork on the window and door frames, the stunning fireplace in the living room.

Palau Mornau was originally built in the 15th century for noble families to live in. It was extended and renovated in classic modernist style in the early 19th century, and renovated anew when the museum opened in 2012.
barcelonaHashMarihuanaAndHempMuseum.name: Marihuana and Hemp Museum

barcelonaPavillion.address: Av. de Francesc Ferrer i Guàrdia, 7, Sants-Montjuïc, 08038 Barcelona
barcelonaPavillion.description:
This is place is likely to appeal to architect enthusiasts but it might not be for everyone.

This structure is a replica of a pavilion that was designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Lilly Reich, two important figures in Germany’s modernist movement, both of whom emigrated to the United States as the Nazis tightened their grip on the country.

The building was the German Pavilion for Barcelona’s  International Exposition in 1929. It is famed for its simple form and use of extravagant materials, such as marble, red onyx and travertine.

The place isn’t particularly big, making the entrance fee seem a little on the high side. You can actually see much of the structure from the outside, without paying to go in. You can also enter for free on the first Sunday of every month.
barcelonaPavillion.name: Barcelona Pavillion

barcelonaPhotoCentre.address: Av. del Litoral, 30, Sant Martí, 08005 Barcelona
barcelonaPhotoCentre.description:
This photo gallery was opened in 2020 by MAPFRE, one of Spain’s largest insurance companies. The KBr in its name stands for being the chemical symbol for potassium bromide, a salt used for developing analogue film.

The gallery has two large exhibition areas, a bookstore, an area for educational activities and a multi-purpose auditorium. There is a vending machine on the ground floor for tea and coffee.

The photo exhibitions change all the time, so it is impossible to say what you might find here when you visit. Just check their website for the latest upcoming exhibitions. They usually run two exhibitions at the same time.

The foundation tends to favour contemporary photographers over historical ones, and the centre likes to promote Catalan culture where possible – whether this is through the photographers it chooses to exhibit or the themes of the exhibitions.

In the foundation’s own words: “KBr expresses the continuity of our exhibition project as well as our commitment to collaborating with other Catalan institutions focusing on photography, to being involved in training future generations in the understanding of the photographic language and to contribute, from the fascinating life witness that photography represents, to the international projection of Barcelona’s creativity and energy.”

The foundation also organises regular talks and seminars from visiting photographers.
barcelonaPhotoCentre.name: KBr Photography Centre

bigFunMuseum.address: Rambla de Sant Josep, 88-94, Ciutat Vella, 08002 Barcelona
bigFunMuseum.description:
This is one of those places that you can’t fail to ignore while ambling down La Rambla. Just those three loud and colourful words – Big, Fun, Museum – are enough to make passersby stop and think: will the museum really be as “fun” as all the literature is saying it will be?

Our verdict is that, yes, it is. Kids will certainly enjoy it, and most adults will find it quite interesting too.

The Big Fun Museum consists of eight separate attractions spread across three floors. There’s the Sweet Museum, for example, and the somewhat disturbing Museum of Madness. Each area consists of a series of well-designed displays, according to the theme, as well as some very interesting explanations. Learn, for example, all about the legend of the Moth-Man and the smallest woman that ever lived.

Much of the museum is suitable for children from the age of four, but certain areas may be quite scary for very young kids.

Giant’s House, Topsy-Turvy House, the Sweet Museum and Alice Through the Looking Glass can all be enjoyed by the younger members of your family.

Parts of Records and Wonders and the Madness Museum are more suitable for older children, from the age of seven or eight.

The Madness Museum has an age recommendation of 12. Some of the animations in the Magic Room – such as the dancing skeletons – can be a little frightening, too.
bigFunMuseum.name: Big Fun Museum

casaMila.address: Pg. de Gràcia, 92, L'Eixample, 08008 Barcelona, Spain
casaMila.description:
Even before stepping inside, Casa Milà has Gaudism written all over it: undulating waves, distinctive rooftop crenelations, beautifully-crafted windows.

It is little wonder that tourists line up on the other side of the road to take photos of this fabulous modernist architecture. It is this stone façade that gives the building its popular nickname, La Pedrera, which means ‘The Quarry’ in Catalan.

Inside is just as one might expect from Gaudí’s modernist period. Each room is uniquely designed, taking inspiration from the natural world and intended to be as light and airy as possible.

The attic is a particularly unique feature of the building, with 270 brick arches made to resemble the inside of a whale’s stomach. On fine days the rooftop is also highly worth visiting, offering fabulous views over the city. The stone chimneys look like armies of soldiers protecting the city, which is what inspired Catalan poet Pere Gimferrer to call the rooftop the Garden of Warriors – a name that appears to have stuck.

The free audio guide adds to the experience, with clear and engaging descriptions that transport the visitor into the architect’s mind. The commentary is related in the first person, as though it is Gaudí speaking about the building he created. A particularly nice feature of the audio is how the narration changes based on the room that the visitor is in. As soon as the visitor is out of a particular area, the audio will switch automatically to another track.

Casa Milà was originally commissioned by Roser Segimón and Pere Milà. Segimón was the wealthy widow of a former colonist who made his fortune with a coffee plantation in Guatemala.

The building was declared a World Heritage Site by Unesco in 1984.
casaMila.name: Casa Milà - La Pedrera

casaVicens.address: Carrer de les Carolines, 20-26, Gràcia, 08012 Barcelona, Spain
casaVicens.description:
This is Antoni Gaudi’s first major work, completed when the architect was just 31.

The building was commissioned by Manuel Vicens i Montaner, a prominent stock and currency broker at the time. It is based on a type of architecture known as Mudéjar, which was popular across the Iberian peninsula between the 13th and 16th centuries. Gaudi also embraced oriental and neoclassical elements into the building’s design.

While the building is perhaps less ostentatious than some of Gaudi’s other works, it is arguably one of his most important ones since it exhibits features that appear in his later modernist masterpieces. Vicens’s house also tends to be less crowded than many other more popular Gaudi buildings.

Floral and geometric patterns dominate the interior of the house. The original project had a large garden area, in addition to the house, but over time the land was subdivided and sold for the construction of residential buildings. Nowadays, the property has been reduced to the house and a small surrounding area.

Halfway through the house there is an informative video explaining its history. The video loops in Catalan, Spanish, and English. The excellent audio guide also helps to bring the place to life.
casaVicens.name: Casa Vicens

chocolateMuseum.address: Carrer del Comerç, 36, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona
chocolateMuseum.description:
An entire museum dedicated to the making of chocolate – do you honestly need another reason to pay a visit?

The museum spans only a few rooms, but it offers a fascinating glimpse into the history of chocolate and Spain’s longstanding relationship with the confectionery.

The carefully-curated displays explain why chocolate was so important for the Aztecs and other ancient cultures of Latin America. The museum also takes visitors on a journey through the history of chocolate in Europe – how a basic recipe for the syrupy black substance was turned into the refined art that the chocolate industry is today.

Towards the end of the museum there are also some really cool sculptures made out of chocolate, including an intricately-fashioned Sagrada Familia, Tintin and a space rocket, scenes from Asterix and Obelisk and the house from the Disney movie Up.

There’s a shop upon exit where you can buy some tasty chocolate. You can also eat the ticket that you use to enter. It, too, is made of chocolate.
chocolateMuseum.name: Chocolate Museum

cosmoCaixa.address: Carrer d'Isaac Newton, 26, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08022 Barcelona
cosmoCaixa.description:
The interactive nature of Barcelona’s top science museum is guaranteed to be a hit with kids. Explanations are clear and illuminating.

Permanent highlights include the “Flooded Forest” (a recreated fragment of the Brazilian rainforest featuring live animals such as birds, fishes and even a capybara), a 3-D planetarium (costs extra), a large area of interactive exhibits where children can learn through experimentation and a micrarium (a place for exploring worlds not visible to the naked eye).

CosmoCaixa also hosts regular temporary exhibitions, which change every few months or so.

There is certainly plenty to see throughout the museum, and you will need a good few hours to take everything in.

The museum has a large and spacious dining hall. Prices are reasonable and the quality is good.
cosmoCaixa.name: Science Museum (CosmoCaixa)

designMuseum.address: Plaça de les Glòries Catalanes, 38, c, Sant Martí, 08018 Barcelona
designMuseum.description:
This museum showcases musical instruments from around the world. Some of these are very old and rare, such as the beautifully-painted Chinese instruments made out of dried pumpkin skins.

The audio guide is very nicely designed. You can choose one of several tracks to accompany your journey around the museum: “general itinerary” (good for first time visitors), “family itinerary”, “the world of sound” and “through a luthier’s eyes”.

The family itinerary is made for kids and rather fun. Children have to follow clues that will lead them to musical instruments shaped like particular animals.

The museum isn’t terribly big, but since the audio guide has multiple tracks you can wander around a few times, each time with a different experience.
designMuseum.name: Design Museum

eroticMuseum.address: La Rambla, 96 bis, 96 bis, Ciutat Vella, 08002 Barcelona
eroticMuseum.description:
The free glass of cava that visitors are handed when they enter the museum lends a certain air of elegant sophistication to visiting this particular museum, as though one is ambling around an art gallery with glass in hand rather than studying walls adorned with pornographic images.

Barcelona’s museum of erotica is a deeply fascinating place to visit. This is not a place to come if you are searching for erotic titillation. Rather, the curated displays take visitors on a captivating historical journey of humanity’s relationship with sex through the ages, featuring such highlights as the distinctly uncomfortable-looking ‘pleasure chair’ and the erotic film collection of former Spanish King Alfonso XIII.

Throughout the 14 rooms, visitors are offered an insight into how sex has been perceived by different cultures over the centuries, learning which civilisations were the most enlightened (the Romans, apparently) and which civilisations were less tolerant.

The authentic artefacts in the museum (such as the weird and wonderful pleasure devices invented over the years) bring the place to life, while the fascinating descriptions pinned to the walls are certain to leave a lasting impression on visitors’ minds.

The museum is not particularly big, but you can easily spend an hour or two getting lost in all that it has to offer.
eroticMuseum.name: Erotic Museum

ethnographyMuseum.address: Carrer de Montcada, 12 - 14, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona
ethnographyMuseum.description:
In 2017, Museu Etnològic and the Museu de Cultures del Món became a single museum with two homes: one close in the gothic quarter of the city and the other on top of Montjuic. This particular entry pertains to the museum that is in the heart of the gothic quarter.

The museum takes visitors on a fascinating journey through the ancient cultures of four distinct regions: Africa, Asia, Oceania and South America.

It has an impressively rich collection of artefacts, with carved wooden figurines and ceremonious masks from all over the world.

The exhibition is extremely well put together. Fascinating explanations of each culture are peppered throughout (in English, Spanish and Catalan). The English descriptions are clear and well-written.

The cultures of Asia and Oceania definitely take centre stage. It’s a shame that the displays skirt over East Africa and don’t really touch on the rest of the continent.
ethnographyMuseum.name: Museum of World Cultres

ethnologyMuseum.address: Passeig de Santa Madrona, 16, Sants-Montjuïc, 08038 Barcelona
ethnologyMuseum.description:
This is the little sister of the Museum of World Cultures, found in the centre of Barcelona. The two were combined into a single entity, albeit at different locations, in 2017.
While the Museum of World Cultures takes visitors on a tour of ethnography across the globe, the Museum of Ethnology looks at the subject through the prism of Catalonia.

A large swathe of the museum is given over to the cultures of the Pyrenees, which demarcates the border between France and Spain. The museum takes a look at how people used to live elsewhere in the region, too.

The museum isn’t terribly big. Its permanent exhibition is located on the ground floor, while the upper floor is given over to temporary displays that changes every six months or so.
ethnologyMuseum.name: Ethnology Museum

europeanMuseumOfModernArt.address: Carrer de la Barra de Ferro, 5, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona
europeanMuseumOfModernArt.description:
Just around the corner from the much more famous Picasso Museum is a somewhat understated gallery of modern European art.

The museum, which is spread over three floors, is dedicated to figurative art from the 20th and 21st centuries. It is housed in a wonderful neoclassical building from the 18th Century.

The museum has both a permanent exhibition and temporary ones, which are changed every few months or so.
europeanMuseumOfModernArt.name: European Museum of Modern Art

fredericMaresMuseum.address: Plaça Sant Iu, 5, Ciutat Vella, 08002 Barcelona
fredericMaresMuseum.cost: Children (under 16): free; Youth (16-29): €2.40; Adult (30 to 64): €4.20; Senior: free
fredericMaresMuseum.description:
This is an astonishing museum, and completely understated. It is not one that is likely to be on the must-see list of most visitors to Barcelona, and yet ambling through the great halls of the museum, which are spread over four floors, is an unforgettable experience.

Frederic Marès was an artist and sculptor who, during his extensive lifetime (he lived to be nearly one hundred, dying in 1991) collected an enormous array of Hispanic sculptures from the ancient world up until the 19th century.
