The ground floor and the basement are taken up with wooden and stone sculptures throughout the ages, mostly of biblical scenes and figures. There are few explanations to go with them, beyond the rough period in which they were fashioned, but it is extremely fascinating to wander through the halls, marvelling at the differences between the carvings and seeing how these change through the ages.

The sculpture collection on these two floors is vast, but there are many more wonders to behold on the upper floors as well.

On the second floor you will find the Collector’s Cabinet, showcasing tens of thousands of objects that take visitors on a journey into past lifestyles and customs by documenting what people used to collect: fans, clocks, cameras, theatre tickets and many other trinkets besides. “Jaw dropping” is the word that springs most readily to mind.

The collections just go on and on. Thousands upon thousands of items, all huddled together in different categories, waiting to capture the visitor’s imagination. It is just a shame that they are so poorly labelled; you need to use your imagination to figure out what tales these items tell of ages gone by.

And the museum doesn’t stop there! The collections continue on the uppermost floor as well, with a section dedicated to memorabilia from the performing arts.

The building in which the museum is housed is impressive, too: a complex of historical edifices that once served as residences for the various counts of Barcelona and the kings of Aragon. This is where the Spanish Inquisition once had its regional headquarters.

Take a moment to look around the courtyard and the famous steps leading out of the complex... and breathe in the history.
fredericMaresMuseum.name: Frederic Marès Museum

fundacioJoanMiro.address: Parc de Montjuïc, s/n, Sants-Montjuïc, 08038 Barcelona
fundacioJoanMiro.cost: €15 (€9 for students and seniors, children under 15 are free)
fundacioJoanMiro.description:
Joan Miró was a Catalan painter and sculptor born in the late 1890s. While he is widely regarded as a surrealist artist, contemporary critics have emphasised his more personal style, borrowing elements from Fauvism and Expressionism. This is a point strongly re-enforced by a visit to the Joan Miró Foundation, where the works on display highlight a wonderfully diverse career over many decades. The artist died in 1983 and was painting right up to his death!

The museum is relatively big and one can easily spend a couple of hours getting lost in the works of Miró and his contemporaries. The building is airy and very well-lit – the perfect conditions under which to appreciate such art.

And the views are fantastic! Right on the edge of Montjuic Park, the art gallery offers visitors the panoramic splendour of the whole of Barcelona – with Tibidabo winking in the distance. If you’ve got extra time, why not take a stroll around the very pleasant Jardins de Laribal just outside?

Most of the museum is taken up with a permanent display, showcasing the various works of Miró over the years. Many of these works were donated to the museum by Miró or his wife.
.
The museum also hosts regular temporary exhibitions, which are usually linked in some way to surrealism or other forms of modern art.

The artworks are mostly indoors, but there are some pieces (especially in the temporary exhibitions) housed outside. This allows visitors to appreciate the art while absorbing the breathtaking views at the same time.

The museum first opened its doors in June 1975, just months before the death of Spain’s dictator Francisco Franco. Like other Catalan artists of his time, Miró had long used artistic expression to oppose Francoist repression, but few such art galleries were welcomed under Franco’s rule.

There is also a reasonably-priced café attached to the museum, where you can grab a drink and bite to eat – and, yes, take in those fabulous views once more.
fundacioJoanMiro.name: Joan Miró Foundation

gaudiExperience.description:
This is a rather fun 4D movie that takes you on an entertaining journey through the works of Antoni Gaudi.

The cartoony graphics are beautifully done. If you enjoy Gaudi it is wonderful to see his architectural masterpieces burst into 3-dimensional life before your eyes. There are no words in the show, only soothing music, so it doesn’t matter what language you speak.

The main show is preceded by a separate cartoon, featuring one of Gaudi’s famous colourful lizards parading around the cinema.

It’s all a lot of fun, but unfortunately quite short. It’s all over in less than 30 minutes.

As one might expect for a Gaudi-themed experience, the place gets extremely busy too.
gaudiExperience.name: Gaudi Experience
gaudiExperience.openingHours: Nov-Mar: 10am to 4.30pm; Apr-Jun & Sep-Oct: 10am to 6.30pm; Jul-Aug: 10am to 8pm

laCapella.address: Carrer de l'Hospital, 56, Ciutat Vella, 08001 Barcelona
laCapella.description:
La Capella is a small exhibition centre for displaying works of contemporary art, housed in the chapel of a former hospital.

The exhibition area is not very big at all, consisting of the main area where prayers would have taken place and an unassuming antechamber off to one side.

Time spent among the works of art, therefore, is likely to be limited. However, the gallery is also worth visiting for the building itself, which boasts some beautiful gothic architecture and comes with a rich history.

Work on the chapel began in 1401 following a papal decree from the Pope Benedict XII. The decree also supported the foundation of the hospital.

The chapel was eventually completed in 1444. It was heavily reconditioned in the 18th Century, and a number of restoration projects were carried out in the 20th Century.

The chapel has been dedicated to displaying works since 1994. The art displays change every few months or so.
laCapella.name: La Capella

maritimeMuseum.address: Av. de les Drassanes, s/n, Ciutat Vella, 08001 Barcelona
maritimeMuseum.description:
Catalonia has a rich seafaring history, and this impressive maritime museum really brings things to life.

The museum is housed in the former Royal Shipyards of Barcelona. The models of the ships are beautifully crafted, while the accompanying explanations are wonderfully engaging – so much so that, although the museum isn’t terribly big, one could easily lose a good few hours digesting every scrap of information that there is to be had.

For everything else that is interesting, the star attraction of the museum must surely be the full-scale replica of a galley ship from the 16th century. Visitors can walk all the way around the ship, really getting a sense of how vast the vessel was. The original craft was 60 meters long, with a depth of just over two metres. It was powered by 59 oars and the strength of 236 rowers. Truly striking. It is also possible to see the ship from above.

The building is very impressive, too.
maritimeMuseum.name: Maritime Museum

moco.address: Carrer de Montcada, 25, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona, Spain
moco.description:
This is kind of a Who’s Who of people that are well known in the world of modern art: Andy Warhol, Banksy, Keith Haring, Jean-Michel Basquiat.

For those that feel that they are curious or interested in modern art but are not experts they will be able to find artists that will be more recognisable and less obscure than those exhibited in other galleries around the city.

The curated collections offer alternative and thought provoking views of the world. The viewing galleries are spacious, with plenty of space to step back from the works of art. The many colourful and relevant explanations help visitors understand what the artists are trying to convey.

However, for contemporary art aficionados, this can be a lot off-putting, with a lot of depth and nuance lost in how the museum has been curated. A bit like an avid music fan going to a nightclub and discovering that all the music being played is pop.

It is a little surprising, and maybe a bit disappointing, that the gallery isn’t bigger than it is.
moco.name: Moco

montjuic.description:
Montjuic Castle

Montjuic Castle not only commands stunning views over Barcelona. It is also a vital part of the city’s colourful history, having been the setting for numerous bloody episodes throughout its 400-year history.

“This fortress is to Barcelona what the Bastille was to Paris or the Peter and Paul Fortress to Saint Petersburg,” wrote journalist Joseph Kessel of the castle in 1956.

Montjuic Castle has been used to bombard the city of Barcelona on a number of occasions, brutally suppressing popular uprisings and revolts. One of the most famous periods for this was between 1842 and 1856, when growing tension with Madrid – as well as economic hardship – saw multiple attempts to topple the regional government.

Definitely come for the views. You can take these in without even buying a ticket: the perimeter of the castle is free to explore.

If you enjoy history, it is certainly worth venturing inside the buiding as well. There are a series of museums and galleries within the structure. Some of these are permanent, documenting the history of the castle in an engaging and informative way. Others are temporary, and likely to change from time to time.

There is a small cafeteria and an ice-cream truck in the castle’s courtyard. If the weather is fine, it is lovely to sit here and relax in the sunshine. Prices are reasonable.
montjuic.name: Montjuic Castle

museumOfContemporaryArt.address: Plaça dels Àngels, 1, Ciutat Vella, 08001 Barcelona
museumOfContemporaryArt.description:
This museum displays contemporary art from the second half of the twentieth century until the present day. Much of the work comes from Spain, but works from artists across Europe and in Latin American also feature a lot. Exhibitions change regularly.

The gallery is housed in a pristinely white building designed by American architect Richard Meier, who has also worked on a number of iconic buildings in the United States. The airy and well-lit rooms present a perfect venue for viewing this kind of art.

One additional feature of the museum that’s quite interesting is the skateboard community that lingers outside, executing skateboard stunts and filming them for online videos.
museumOfContemporaryArt.name: Museum of Contemporary Art
museumOfContemporaryArt.openingHours: Mon & Wed-Fri: 11.30am to 7.30pm; Sat: 10am to 8pm; Sun: 10am to 3pm

museumOfProhibitedArt.address: Carrer de la Diputació, 250, L'Eixample, 08007 Barcelona, Spain
museumOfProhibitedArt.description:
This is a wonderfully thought-provoking museum: a place to come and see those artworks from around the world that have been banned, censored or withdrawn from public view.

It is fascinating to see those creations that have caused offence in certain cultures of the world – like a room full of Islamic prayer mats with ladies’ high-heeled shoes upon them, or a painting of the Crucifixion soaked in urine or a picture that was slashed for the provocative way in which the Virgin Mary was displayed.

While respecting culturally sensitivities is important, this museum shows that artistic expression can transcend this. Those that are likely to be offended to not have to view the works of art on display, but for others visiting the museum offers a fascinating glimpse into the power that art has to challenge one’s belief and perceptions.

*When we visited the museum, some former members of staff were protesting outside about the working conditions within the museum. The museum’s management say that they do not work at the museum. This is true. They work for another company, which the museum recently terminated a contract with. The protestors are claiming unfair dismissal, which the museum is contesting. Legal proceedings are ongoing.*
museumOfProhibitedArt.name: Museum of Prohibited Art

museumOfTheHistoryOfCatalonia.address: Pça. de Pau Vila, 3, Ciutat Vella, 08039 Barcelona
museumOfTheHistoryOfCatalonia.description:
This museum charts the rich history of the Catalan region from prehistoric times (circa 200,000 BC) right up to the modern day, with the final displays reinforcing the importance of preserving the local language and culture.

The museum has a rich collection of artefacts from bygone eras, and a huge amount of information that you can read as you wander around.

If you were to take in everything, you could easily spend three or four hours meandering between the display cabinets. The best way to visit the museum is to focus on those areas that you are most interested in, and then spend more time delving into these.

The information plaques scattered throughout the museum can feel a bit dry at times, especially if you don’t know a period particularly well, but models throughout the museum really help bring things to life: the knight on horseback, the longboat carrying goods to trade, the replica of an irrigation system for nourishing crops.

The museum is spread over three floors.

The first floor is given over to a temporary exhibition, which changes every few months or so. The second floor deals with Catalan history from the prehistoric period right up until the start of the 18th century. The top floor charts the course of history in the 18th and 19th century, right up to the present day.

There are separate tickets for the temporary and the permanent exhibition, or you can buy a combined ticket.

There is a sense that the museum rather glosses over the modern part of Catalan history, from the second half of the last century up to the present day. There is astonishingly little about the Franco era, for instance. This is a bit of shame, given the importance of this period in shaping Catalonia’s identity.

Most of the information is in English, but some of the smaller displays are only labelled in Spanish and Catalan.
museumOfTheHistoryOfCatalonia.name: History of Catalonia Museum
museumOfTheHistoryOfCatalonia.openingHours: Tue & Thu-Sat: 10am to 7pm; Wed: 10am to 8pm; Sun: 10am to 2.30pm

musicMuseum.description:
This is a very interesting museum that showcases musical instruments from around the world. Some of these are very old and rare, such as the beautifully-painted Chinese instruments made out of dried pumpkin skins.

The audio guide is beautifully designed. You can choose one of several tracks to accompany you as you wonder around the museum: “general itinerary” (good for first time visitors), “family itinerary”, “the world of sound” and “through a luthier’s eyes”.

This means that visitors can wonder around the museum more than once, each time enjoying a slightly different experience.

The family itinerary is made for kids and rather fun. Children have to follow clues that will them to musical instruments shaped like particular animals.

The museum isn’t terribly big, but since the audio guide has multiple tracks you can wonder around a few times, each time with a different experience.
musicMuseum.name: Music Museum

picassoMuseum.address: Carrer de Montcada, 15-23, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona
picassoMuseum.description:
As one might expect for a museum dedicated to someone who is arguably Spain’s most famous artist, this place is almost always busy. While the museum is certainly worth visiting for anyone who likes Pablo Picasso’s paintings and those of his contemporaries, the relentless crowds can make appreciating the artwork in all its glory somewhat challenging.

The museum is divided into three parts.

The first part, shortly after the entrance, exhibits paintings from Catalan artists that lived and worked at the same time as Picasso. People like Santiago Rusiñol, Miquel Utrillo, Enric Clarassó and Ramon Canudas.

The second part of the museum covers Picasso’s early works, including his so-called “blue period”, where the artist divided his time between Spain and Paris.

The third part of the museum delves into his later cubist and neoclassical phase.

There is also a small exhibition on the work that the artist did with pottery.

It is a very interesting and well put-together museum. The visitor comes away with an awesome sense of what Picasso was able to achieve in his generous lifetime. There is also an audio guide that adds additional layers of colour to the museum, but this costs extra.

On especially busy days tickets for the Picasso Museum can be sold out. You can reserve tickets in advance online.

The museum also offers a limited number of tickets for "free admission days". Check the website for details.
picassoMuseum.name: Picasso Museum

pobleEspanyol.address: Av. de Francesc Ferrer i Guàrdia, 13, Sants-Montjuïc, 08038 Barcelona
pobleEspanyol.description:
Poble Espanyol is an open-air museum, featuring more than a hundred full-scale replicas of buildings from all over the country. It was first established in 1929 as part of an international exposition held in Barcelona that year. There is a permanent exhibition that tells you all about this unique project on the first floor next to the main square.

The place can feel a little bit touristy, full of over-priced restaurants and streets lined with craft shops. However, it is a nice place to visit to appreciate some of the diverse architecture that Spain has to offer, without having to travel hundreds of miles around the country.

The place also puts on great events for special occasions throughout the year, such as Halloween, Easter, Christmas and other celebrations that take place throughout the calendar year.

For families with kids, there are a few  very long slides near the church.
pobleEspanyol.name: Poble Espanyol

tapiesMuseum.description:
The Tàpies museum was founded by local artist Antoni Tàpies to promote the appreciation of contemporary art. Tàpies himself was particularly drawn to surrealism, and used art as a way of conveying his dislike of the dictatorship of Francisco Franco. A Catalan through and through, he used his art to keep the regional culture alive.

The well-lit museum covers three floors (plus a terrace), but the works of art are fairly spread out, meaning that you should need no more than an hour to appreciate everything.

Exhibitions run throughout the year and are usually based around the works of a particular artist. They change every six months or so. As one might expect for a museum bearing his name, the works of Tàpies appear regularly.

Most exhibitions are accompanied by an audio guide, which can be downloaded onto the phone and listened to at leisure. These guides are extremely informative and well put together.

The museum is housed in the former headquarters of the Editorial Montaner y Simón publishing house. The building, completed in the early 1880s, is representative of early Catalan Modernism. The structure was ahead of its time, using brick and iron to create particularly large and airy rooms.
.
The museum´s library contains a huge catalogue of documents and books pertaining to Tàpies, as well as other literature about contemporary art and architecture. Access to the library is by appointment only.
tapiesMuseum.name: Tàpies Museum

tibidabo.description:
Barcelona’s only amusement park might not be able to compete with the thrills-and-spills of Europe´s top theme parks that you find elsewhere in Europe, but it must surely be one of the most visually-appealing ones on the continent.

You can spot Tibidabo from miles away, identified by a grandiose church (The Church of the Sacred Heart), built in the early 20th Century.

A smattering of traditional fairground rides (a Ferris wheel, a merry-go-round and a couple of others) cluster around the church, but the bulk of the rides are at lower levels.

You can pay individually for the rides on the uppermost level, while the rides at lower levels are only accessible with a day ticket.

The rides at the top of the park are operational every day, but the rest of the park only runs at weekends and during school holidays. Make sure you check opening times before you set out!

There are a total of 32 rides and activities in the park, spread across five floors. Popular ones include bumper cars, the classic log flume, a 4D cinema, a house of mirrors and a few (relatively tame) roller coasters.

Children who are taller than 120 centimetres will be allowed on most of the rides.

It is totally free to visit the panoramic area, so you can enjoy the amazing views even if you don’t want to pay to enter the park.
tibidabo.name: Tibidabo
tibidabo.openingHours: Varies according to time of year - consult website

virreinaPalaceAndArtCentre.description: La Virreina Centre de la Imatge is a contemporary art and learning centre in Barcelona, housed in a fabulous 18th-century building right on Las Ramblas. It’s worth visiting for the architecture alone. The free-to-visit temporary art exhibitions are a bonus. The exhibitions change every few months or so. The publicly accessible area is rather small, so plan just a short visit.
virreinaPalaceAndArtCentre.name: Virreina Palace and Art Centre

aCasaPortuguesa.description:
This takeaway-only gem sells authentic Portuguese desserts and savoury street food. It faces a charming square with benches, perfect for enjoying these tasty treats in the fresh air. 

The traditional Portuguese custard tarts (*pasteis de nata*) are excellent. The quiches are also very good.

A sweet little slice of Portugal right in the heart of Gracia.

It is possible to order online.
aCasaPortuguesa.name: A Casa Portuguesa

bacoaUniversitat.address: Ronda de la Univ., 31, L'Eixample, 08007 Barcelona, Spain
bacoaUniversitat.description: Delicious, high-quality burgers just a short walk from Plaça Catalunya. By Barcelona standards, the space is quite large with plenty of seating. They don’t offer combos, but the menu includes a range of tasty options that can be customised according to taste. There’s no table service—you order at the counter.
bacoaUniversitat.name: Bacoa Universitat

baos.address: Carrer de la Independència, 258, local 1, Sant Martí, 08026 Barcelona, Spain
baos.description:
Bao's

This is a terrific Asian restaurant that serves freshly-prepared gyoza dumplings and silky bao buns. 

The bao buns are the signature dish, and definitely worth coming for: light, soft and oozing with flavour. Many Chinese restaurants in Barcelona serve bao buns that are too heavy or have a cardboard texture, so it is refreshing to find ones that are so good.

The gyoza are excellent, too: freshly prepared right on the counter.

In fact, there’s not a dish that we wouldn’t recommend. Definitely give the noodle dishes a try – highly flavoursome.

Prices are reasonable, though unfortunately portions are a little small. Still, it’s nice to order a few to share - you can always order more if you are still hungry!

The place isn’t hug, perhaps no more than half a dozen tables inside and a couple that are outside.

Staff are friendly and have a smattering of English.

This is a very good place for take-away, too.
baos.name: Bao's

benditoFuoco.description:
Some great Italian cooking is on offer here – both in terms of the pasta and the tasty pizzas. The restaurant excels at big, punchy flavours. Although his can be a bit overbearing for an entire meal, the accompanying bread helps balance things out. The restaurant does a very reasonably-priced menu al dia for lunch, including a generous starter, main course, dessert (or coffee) and a drink. The parmigiana di melanzane as a starter is very good.

The service of the restaurant leaves a little bit to be desired, however. The waiters seem fairly inexperienced, and don’t have a particularly good understanding of the dishes that are on the menu

The place has a nice atmosphere, but can be a bit cold, especially in winter and when it is half-full.
benditoFuoco.name: Bendito Fuoco

boDeB.address: Carrer Merce, Carrer de la Mercè, 35, bajos, Ciutat Vella, 08002 Barcelona
boDeB.description:
This is a very good sandwich shop, serving fresh baguettes packed with all sorts of tasty ingredients, as well as salads and a few other dishes.

The place has become a bit of an iconic lunch spot in the city, made famous by YouTube and TikTok videos.

This means that there are often lengthy queues outside, and during peak times (especially in the summer) you may have to wait up to an hour to get served. You will have to weigh up whether the desire to sink your teeth into a good baguette (and they really are very good) is worth the time that you will be waiting outside the place beforehand.

Such social media influence also means that the place has a decidedly expat feel to it; you are more likely to find English-speaking customers here than locals!

Nonetheless, as already noted, the place is very good, and worth trying if you are nearby. Despite clearly being very busy, staff are very friendly and helpful. There is a Middle Eastern flavour to many of the fillings and sauces that customers can choose from.

The place isn’t terribly big (no more than half a dozen tables inside, and these are usually taken), but you can always order to go.
boDeB.name: Bo de B

bodegaLaPalma.address: Carrer de la Palma de Sant Just, 7, Ciutat Vella, 08002 Barcelona
bodegaLaPalma.description:
If you want to sample some of the best vermut that the city has to offer, while gorging yourself on plates of delicious tapas, Bodega La Palma is the place to come.

Tucked away down one of the many charming narrow streets of Barcelona’s Gothic Quarter, the small bar is positively steeped in nostalgia and olde-worlde charm. Vintage wine bottles line the shelves. Dim lighting sets a relaxed, intimate mood.

La Palma first opened as a grocery store in 1935, but five years later became a winery, as well as a meeting point for the intellectuals of the day. The bar is now owned by Albert Rial and Judith Giménez, who have pledged to uphold the local tradition that has made the place so well-known.

The place isn’t terribly big so it is definitely worth booking in advance. Menus are available in English, Spanish and Catalan.

While there is a good selection of drink on offer (including, beer, wine and spirits), a lot of people come here to sample the homemade vermut. This really is excellent: subtly-spiced and not overbearing.

Food is traditionally Catalan. Try the slow cooked pork, the cannelloni with truffle and the mussels. Although the restaurant offers a menu of the day, this is mostly aimed at locals in search of a quick and affordable lunch. We recommend ordering à la carte.
bodegaLaPalma.name: Bodega La Palma

cafeSolo.description:
This is a cozy spot focused on quality coffee and fresh food. It offers healthier options than many Barcelona cafés. Most items are made fresh on the spot. Try the avocado, peanuts, and egg on toast, for instance. Sumtuous.

A great place for a light, nourishing break.

The décor is minimalist.
cafeSolo.name: Café Solo

calPep.address: Plaça de les Olles, 8, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona, Spain
calPep.description:
One of the best seafood spots in the Born area. Booking is only possible for groups of four or more, otherwise you’ll be seated at the lively counter where you can watch the chefs in action.

Staff are friendly and many speak English. The food is fresh, seasonal, and delicious. Prices are a little on the high side and queues are common — but the wait is worth it!
calPep.name: Cal Pep

canSardi.address: Carrer del Consell de Cent, 340, BAJO LOCAL, L'Eixample, 08009 Barcelona
canSardi.description:
This is a good place to pop into if you're after some cheap and tasty Italian focaccia sandwiches.

The place isn’t terribly big (perhaps no more than a dozen people can fit comfortably inside), but the atmosphere is cosy and welcoming, with soft music (often Italian) playing in the background. Service is extremely friendly, too.

Besides focaccia, the place also serves a menú del día featuring other Italian dishes, such as gnocchi and pasta.

Don’t expect anything too gourmet, but for a quick bit to eat this place definitely ticks all the right boxes. Portions are a little bit on the small side.
canSardi.name: Can Sardi

chenJi.description:
This could easily be a local diner on the streets of Shanghai (apart from the large numbers of non-Chinese customers, of course). Don’t expect anything too fancy. The place is busy and noisy, service is fast, portions are huge and prices are low.

With hearty mains typically costing less than €10, you’ll certainly be leaving satisfied and with money still in the bank.

Some of the dishes could be better seasoned and the portions are so huge that one can get a bit bored when ploughing through a single dish (better to share a few). But in terms of fast, cheap and tasty food, this restaurant ticks all the right boxes.
chenJi.name: Chen Ji

chocolatBox.address: Carrer Major de Sarrià, 45, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08017 Barcelona
chocolatBox.description:
Chocolat-Box

This must be one of the best places in Barcelona to come for truly authentic Italian ice-creams. Although this is a chain, the outlet in Sarria is by far the best - both in terms of quality and in terms of service. Maybe this has something to do with the number of Italians living in or close to Sarria, and its proximity to an Italian school…

The gelateria offers a great range of flavours and all are very good. Portions (even for the ‘small’ size) are huge. Try and persuade your kid to go for the smaller size - even then, they probably won’t be able to finish it!

Although the main reason to come here is for the ice-cream, the place also serves decent coffee, churros, hot chocolate and more besides.

The place isn’t terribly big. There are seating options inside and a couple of tables outside as well.
chocolatBox.name: Chocolat-Box

chromaticCafé.address: Carrer de les Carolines, 26, Gràcia, 08012 Barcelona, Spain
chromaticCafé.description: This is a stylish little café with a dark, modern vibe. It serves great coffee and excellent homemade cookies—some of them vegan. The only downside is its location next to a (very good) fishmonger, which can occasionally affect the aroma inside, esecially during summer.
chromaticCafé.name: Chromatic Café
chromaticCafé.openingHours: Mon-Tue & Thu-Fri: 8.30am to 7.30pm; Wed: 8.30am to 2pm; Sat: 9.30am to 7.30pm; Sun: 9.30am to 6.30pm

denassus.description:
A terrific little wine bar with some great tapas. The setting is cosy and intimate, perfect for a romantic meal or for dining with a small group of close friends. There is some outside seating, too. If you come on your own, you may be asked to sit at the bar – which is no bad thing as you can then chat with the friendly and welcoming staff.
Denassus is an independent establishment, run by two friends who also produce their own wine in a vineyard south of Barcelona. They have two bottles of white available at the bar, plus a bottle of bubbly. Besides their own wine, they also offer a carefully-selected range of wine from other producers – so if you feel like exploring Catalan vintages this is a good place to try.
The food might be best described as authentic Catalan fare with a stylish twist: baby squid in a sumptuous white bean broth, grilled leek with a citrus and agave vinaigrette, patatas bravas topped with a parsley-aioli fusion. The duck croquette comes highly recommended. Definitely a place to return to.
denassus.name: Denassus

elCanalla.address: Carrer Major de Sarrià, 95, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08017 Barcelona
elCanalla.description:
Tasty Catalan cuisine with fresh fish options, and one of the better dining choices in Sarrià.

There’s a terrace. The menu includes tapas and lunch set meals.

Service can be a bit slow and not overly friendly, but the quality of the food makes up for it.
elCanalla.name: El Canalla

elPicot.address: Parc Natural de la Serra de Collserola, Ctra. de l'Església, 92, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08017 Barcelona
elPicot.description:
The main draw of this place is the location: right in the middle of a national park, an ideal place to stop off for a bit to eat or drink mid-way through a hike.

The place has a lovely terrace where you can sit outside and enjoy the sunshine. There is also a seating area inside.

The food isn’t bad, but it also isn’t outstanding. They serve some good Catalan dishes such as botifarra, rabbit and pan con tomates.  The crema catalana was a bit disappointing.

The place isn’t terribly big so it pays to reserve in advance. At weekends it can get really busy and service can feel rather rushed.
elPicot.name: El Picot

elRacódeCollserola.address: Ctra. de l'Església, km 5, 8, Distrito de Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08017 Barcelona
elRacódeCollserola.description:
This is the perfect place to come for a lazy breakfast in the sunshine. They do amazing Catalan bocadillos (sandwiches). Try the bocadillo serranito (with pork and serrano ham), or the bocadillo de botifara and you won’t be disappointed! Order an extra helping of pimientos verdes (green sweet bell peppers) to go on the top, and you have a breakfast that will really set you up for the day; perfect if you’re planning on doing any hiking in the nearby national park. 

This is the perfect place to come for a lazy breakfast in the sunshine. They do amazing Catalan bocadillos (sandwiches). Try the bocadillo serranito (with pork and serrano ham) or the bocadillo de botifara (with traditional Spanish sausage) and you won’t leave disappointed! Order an extra helping of pimientos verdes (green sweet bell peppers) to go on the top, and you have a breakfast that will really set you up for the day: perfect if you’re planning on doing any hiking in the nearby national park. 

The place also has a few non-meat sandwich options. The coffee and juices here are excellent, too.

There is plenty of seating at the restaurant, both indoors and on the terrace.

The restaurant overlooks a large patch of open land, perfect for kicking a ball around or throwing a frisbee. If you come here with the whole family, the adults can enjoy a pleasant meal in a relaxed settings while the young-at-heart can have a bit of a run-around

The restaurant doesn’t just serve breakfasts. The lunches are also not bad. The restaurant offers a menu del dia during weekdays, although this isn't quite as good as the a-la-carte options.

It’s not usually necessary to book for breakfast – simply turn up at any time before 11am (which is when they stop serving). However, lunch often does require booking in advance, especially at weekends, and especially if you want to find a sunny spot on the terrace (which most people usually do).

This is the perfect place to incorporate into a hike – either with a breakfast before you set off, or with a lunch in the middle / at the end.

There is ample space for parking at the restaurant, too.
elRacódeCollserola.name: El Racó de Collserola

elTomasdeSarria.address: Carrer Major de Sarrià, 49, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08017 Barcelona
elTomasdeSarria.description:
This place is particularly well known for its patatas bravas. They are certainly good, but perhaps not worth going too much out of your way for.

The place usually has a a queue at the door. The decor is basic.

The food is decent though not extraordinary. Still, it’s a local institution and a good casual option for traditional Catalan fare in Sarrià.
elTomasdeSarria.name: El Tomás de Sarrià

elVolador.address: Carrer d'Aribau, 265, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08021 Barcelona, Spain
elVolador.description:
Come to El Volador for some great Mexican food and some of the friendliest staff that you will find in a Barcelona restaurant.

The restaurant has many of the classic favourites (such as tortilla chips loaded with guacamole, quesadillas and tortilla wraps), as well as some authentic Mexican dishes that you may not find in other similar restaurants.

Try the jericalla de maiz for example. This is a traditional Mexican dessert that closely resembles the crema catalana with one important difference – it is made with corn. Very distinctive.

The restaurant also serves a good range of cocktails, including a few traditional Mexican ones, such as spicy micheladas (tomato juice, a dash of lime, a splash of hot sauce and plenty of beer).

This is definitely the place to come if you are after more than your usual run-of-the-mill Mexican restaurant. The pleasant décor also contributes favourably to the whole dining experience.

The menu al dia is very good value.
elVolador.name: El Volador
elVolador.openingHours: Mon-Thu & Sun: 1pm to 4.30pm & 8pm to 12am; Fri-Sat: 1pm to 4.30pm & 8pm to 2am

els4Gats.address: Carrer de Montsió, 3, Ciutat Vella, 08002 Barcelona, Spain
els4Gats.description:
An iconic Catalonian eatery housed in a stunning art nouveau building, which was once a hub for Barcelona’s modernist movement. Indeed, as the proprietors are proud of pointing out, this used to be the old watering hole of Antoni Gaudi.

There are a number of tables at the entrance of the restaurant for casual dining, which cannot be reserved. Further inside is a more formal eating area, where reservations are possible.

Despite the location and fame of this establish, the food has retained its authenticity, and the ambience takes one back in time - perfect for soaking up Barcelona’s history while you eat. Prices may be slightly higher than some of the surrounding restaurants, but not by much.
els4Gats.name: Els 4 Gats

frooty.address: Carrer del Pedró de la Creu, 24, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08034 Barcelona
frooty.description:
This is an organic fruit and veg store with a small café attached. The fresh fruit juices are sublime – a real pick-me-up when you’re done with grocery shopping. The coffee is not bad, either, and there is a decent selection of decent sandwiches.

For a café that goes out of its way to source organic produce, prices are decent.. The place has a very good sandwich-and-juice deal, although the sandwich that forms part of this offer is usually the basic ham-and-cheese one.

There aren’t all that many tables, but as long as you are not a big group you can usually find somewhere to sit. There is one plug where you can charge your laptop if you need to.
Staff are very friendly.

The place has very convenient opening hours as well, including on a Sunday.
frooty.name: Frooty
frooty.openingHours: Mon-Fri: 7am to 9.30pm; Sat: 8am to 9.30pm; Sun: 9am to 9pm

futami.description:
From the first bite of the miso-drizzled salad to the last scoop of matcha-infused ice-cream, this is a Japanese restaurant that screams authenticity.

The Japanese staff are extremely friendly, and diners can watch the chef perform some culinary theatrics in the centre of the restaurant.

A range of classic Japanese dishes are on offer, as well as sushi. Flavours are exceptional and the sushi is fresh. The chicken in the katsu curry is about as crispy as you can get.

The ambience is relaxing, with gentle music playing. You can choose to sit at the bar, watching the chef at work, or at one of the many tables in the place. Limited outdoor seating is also available.

Prices are very reasonable, and the lunchtime menu del dia is good value. Not all of the desserts are authentically Japanese, though.
futami.name: Futami

gastrea.description:
This pincho bar ticks most boxes: delicious food, a convivial atmosphere and a fantastic price-to-quality ratio. 

Most of the seating in the restaurant is around the bar, which allows an opportunity to get a glimpse of what food is on offer and to strike up a conversation with the friendly proprietor (if he is around). The proprietor speaks some English.

There are also a few small tables at the back, but this is not the place to come with a large group.

The restaurant serves both hot and cold pinchos. These are bite-sized morsels, which unlike tapas aren’t usually shared with others. You will need a number of them to fill you up, but you don’t have to order them all at once. Just keep ordering them until you have eaten enough.

The cold pinchos are displayed on the counter, while the hot ones are made-to-order.

The restaurant is also in a great location, just opposite one of the main cinemas in Gracia, so it’s a great place to come before or after seeing a film.

The only thing is that the opening times can be slightly odd, and they do occasionally change from those that are advertised. The restaurant may be closed when the owner is away or on holiday.

The restaurant only accepts cash, which in this day and age can be a bit inconvenient.
gastrea.name: Gasterea

gelatoCollection.description:
This ice-cream parlour was established by Michelin star chef Albert Adrià in partnership with his pastry chef Alfredo Machado.

The quality of the ice-cream is very good: rich, silky and full of flavour. Service is friendly, and staff are always eager to offer advice as to which ice-cream suits your taste. You can have a small taster of any flavour before you make your final decision.

The place has many of the classic varieties, as well as some more exotic ones. Unfortunately, these more interesting flavours, which are labelled in gold, cost quite a bit extra on top of the standard price - a common practice in Barcelona, where ingredients may be more expensive.

There are two varieties of pistachio for instance: regular pistachio and roasted pistachio from Iran. The roasted pistachio has a much more intense flavour, but one has to weigh up whether this really justifies the significantly higher price.

Other premium-priced flavours that could be worth trying include piña colada, campari and orange, hibiscus margarita and kumquat. The alcoholic flavours have real alcohol in them, too!

The interior of the store is modern and minimalist. It’s take-away only.
gelatoCollection.name: Gelato Collection

grooffe.address: Carrer de Sant Gervasi de Cassoles, 37, local 1, Distrito de Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08022 Barcelona, Spain
grooffe.description:
This is a great little café for breakfast or brunch. It closes at 3pm, unfortunately, which rules out afternoon tea.

The place serves excellent tostadas. Try the poached egg served atop a generous helping of avocado, garnished with sun-dried tomato and rocket leaves. The New York bagel and the pulled-pork burger are also very good. 

Grooffe has a section of sweet treats, too, such as pancakes, fruit bowls, yoghurt and granola. These are a bit on the pricey side, though, costing almost as much as the savoury bites.

Croissants, cookies and homemade cakes are also sold here.

The café has a good selection of drinks, from fresh juices, smoothies, cocktails and a great range of matcha beverages.

The place is not really suitable for big families or groups. There is also a small seating area outside. The staff don't allow customers to use their computers during busy periods, such as at weekends.
grooffe.name: Grooffe

kitchen.address: Carrer de la Maquinista, 12, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona
kitchen.description:
This place offers decent and reasonably-priced pizza slices, in an area that is full of tourist traps. The pizza slices are fresh and much better than you might get from similar places in Barcelona.

The restaurant doesn’t have any tables, only a few stools perched against the counter where you can eat.

This is a good option if you want to munch a pizza while you soak up the sun on the nearby beach: perfect for those lazy summer months! Staff are friendly, too.
kitchen.name: Kitchen

lAntiquariGastronòmic.description:
Fine-dining isn't for everyone, but for those that do enjoy gastronomic tasting menus, L'Antiquari Gastronomic is unlikely to disappoint. The food is deliciously inventive and the price, for a five-star eating experience, not at all unreasonable. The tasting menu consists of 14 elegant dishes, each assigned to a particular category: fish, poultry, red meat, vegetables and dessert to finish with. The whole tasting menu is pre-prepared, so the only decision you need to make throughout the entire meal is what wine to order.

Almost all the dishes at L'Antiquari Gastronomic are excellent. Clear stars are duck cannelloni (created in the memory of the chef’s grandmother) and a bisque made from gambero rosso, an Italian shrimp. The restaurant changes most of the dishes on the menu every month, but thankfully these two dishes remain.

The restaurant has an elegant intimacy to it, with soft music and low lighting. Service is excellent, with the dishes arriving at a decent pace: serenely unhurried, allowing ample time for conversation between plates but not leaving diners wondering what has happened to the rest of the meal.

Don’t forget to book ahead if you are planning to come here for a special occasion. The place is usually full for weeks in advance.

One odd point about this restaurant is that it is located on the second floor and the entrance is via another restaurant.

Take care: the floor of l’Antiquari Gastronòmic can be slippery!
lAntiquariGastronòmic.name: L’Antiquari Gastronòmic
lAntiquariGastronòmic.openingHours: Mon & Thu & Sun: 2pm to 4pm & 7.45 to 10.30pm; Fri-Sat: 2pm to 4pm & 7.45pm to 1am

laBikineriaMuntaner.address: C/ de Muntaner, 568, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08022 Barcelona
laBikineriaMuntaner.description: A budget-friendly sandwich shop specializing in Spanish grilled toasties known as ‘bikinis’. This place offers creative fillings that go beyond the classic ham and cheese. There is limited seating. They offer a good-value lunch set. Ideal for a quick and satisfying bite.
laBikineriaMuntaner.name: La Bikineria (Muntaner)

laDeliteca.address: Carrer de Santa Amèlia, 24, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08034 Barcelona
laDeliteca.description:
A hybrid between a deli and a lunch spot, serving authentic Italian food and high-quality sandwiches. The staff are friendly and flexible with special requests.

A great place for a casual and tasty Italian meal. The place also serves grocery products.
laDeliteca.name: La Deliteca

laGastronomica.description: This is a cozy restaurants with great burgers and a super-friendly service. The quality of the meat is excellent. The meat is cooked perfectly to request. The restaurant has a fairly small list of burgers. All are very good. Besides the usual classics, you can also order pulled pork burgers and some with slow-cooked chicken. The caramelised onions are awesome, slowly cooked for at least five hours. Burgers come with homemade fries and a sauce of your choice. Try the homemade spicy mayo – delicious. The high quality of ingredients is noticeable even in the cheese they use. There are a few tables outside. On the downside, the restaurant is fairly small and not really suitable for groups of more than four people.
laGastronomica.name: La Gastronomica

laPuglia.address: Passeig de la Reina Elisenda de Montcada, 7, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi
laPuglia.description:
This is a small Italian eatery, with tasty food from the Puglia region of the country. The family that owns the restaurant come from the area.

The food and service are very good, and there are plenty of Italian options. The Focaccia, which they use to make the sliced pizza, is tasty and filling. The panzarotti (deep fried or oven-baked parcels filled with Italian ingredients, such as tomato and mozzarella) are also very good.

This is also a great place to have an authentic Italian breakfast with filled croissants (pistachios, white chocolate, chocolate or custard).

There are several tables indoors and a couple of standing-only tables outside.

It’s a good option for take-away, too.
laPuglia.name: La Puglia
laPuglia.openingHours: Mon-Wed: 6am to 7pm; Thu: 6am to 9pm; Sat: 8am to 5pm; Sun: 8am to 3pm

lalqila.address: Carrer de Roger de Llúria, 49, L'Eixample, 08009 Barcelona
lalqila.description:
The Indian curries served here are extremely tasty and very authentic. The dishes can be ordered spicy or mild, and when you ask for ‘spicy’ they won’t hold back: the dishes will be as punchy as you’d find in Southern India.

The restaurant also serves grilled meat and kebabs. The quality of the meat is very good as well.

The whole place feels very Indian and service is extremely welcoming. Staff are attentive and keen to make sure that the diners are having a good meal.

Prices are very reasonable, too.
lalqila.name: LalQila

mustafasGemuseKebap.description:
One of the most authentic Turkish kebabs in Barcelona.

Freshly made wraps and a nicely decorated indoor space make it more than just a quick bite. It’s a little taste of Istanbul right here in the heart of Barcelona.

Staff are friendly and ingredients are very fresh.
mustafasGemuseKebap.name: Mustafa’s Gemüse Kebap

napAntic.address: Av. de Francesc Cambó, 30, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona
napAntic.description:
This is an unpretentious Neapolitan restaurant, offering extremely good pizza at very reasonable prices. The house wine (both red and white) is cheap and of not bad quality. Service is friendly and welcoming, with most of the staff being Italian.

The restaurant serves decent starters too. Try the bruschetta, parmigiana and the oven-baked provolone.

The restaurant doesn’t accept bookings, so if you come here at peak times there is a good chance you will have to wait to be seated. However the pizzeria is open throughout the day, so you can always time your visit to come at a time when you know it won’t e so busy.

Most of the tables are indoors, but there is also a small outdoor seating area.

This is a chain, with outlets throughout Barcelona and elsewhere in Spain. This particular branch was the first one that NAP opened.
napAntic.name: NAP Antic

paninaro.description:
You might very well overlook this place in your search for a top-quality sandwich place. This would be a mistake.

With a gaudy exterior and a barely-legible font, this place looks to all intents and purposes to be little more than a fast food joint.

However, this restaurant serves some of the best Italian paninos that you will find in Barcelona, jam-packed with flavour and sandwiched between generous wedges of fresh focaccia.

There is a good range of sandwiches to choose from, from the scrumptious burrata and pesto to the delectable nduja piccante. They all come served with a small pot of crisps.

Draught beer is available, too, and the place has free wi-fi for customers.
paninaro.name: Paninaro

petritxol.address: Carrer de Santa Maria, 24, 08172 Sant Cugat del Vallès, Barcelona
petritxol.description: There are plenty of tourist traps where you can sample pricey and mediocre churros. This is not one of them. The churros are well-balanced and not overly sweet, the accompanying hot chocolate is velvety, rich without being overbearing and positively sublime. Many people descend on this café for this very reason (churros dipped in hot chocolate), but the place offers many other delicacies to placate the sweetest-toothed customer. The place is almost always busy, no matter the time of day or eventide. The best thing you can do if you don’t want to queue is to try and time your visit to avoid the peak crowds. Mid-morning or mid-afternoon usually works well. The place doesn’t accept reservations. Petritxol also sells delectable chocolate.
petritxol.name: Petritxol Sant Cugat

petritxolXocoa.address: Carrer de Petritxol, 11, Ciutat Vella, 08002 Barcelona
petritxolXocoa.description:
There are plenty of tourist traps in the centre of Barcelona where you can sample pricey and mediocre churros. This is not one of them.

The churros are well-balanced and not overly sweet, the accompanying hot chocolate is velvety, rich without being overbearing and positively sublime.

The place offers many other delicacies to placate the sweetest-toothed customer, including a great crema catalana.

The place doesn’t accept reservations. Petritxol also sells delectable chocolate.

There is plenty of seating space inside the restaurant. They also do take away.
petritxolXocoa.name: Petritxol Xocoa

pinkBudaBurgerOldTown.address: Carrer dels Escudellers, 31, Ciutat Vella, 08002 Barcelona
pinkBudaBurgerOldTown.description:
This is a decent smash burger place right in the centre of Barcelona, just off La Rambla.

The burgers are flavoursome, not at all greasy and come with just the right amount of sauce. The accompanying chips are also very good – slightly crunchy and perfectly salted.

The place serves beer, too, although Heineken is the only one on tap. For other varieties, try their reasonably-priced bottled beers. 

Given the name, you won’t be surprised to learn that the place is pink. Extremely pink. This intense pinkness gives the place a warm, relaxing feeling. Staff are generally friendly, happy to advise on what burger best suits your mood.

The place isn’t terribly big, so during peak hours it can be difficult to find a seat. The low lighting can make reading difficult.

All in all, though, this is definitely a good place to turn to if you are after a burger while in the centre of Barcelona.
pinkBudaBurgerOldTown.name: Pink Buda Burger (Old Town)
pinkBudaBurgerOldTown.openingHours: Mon-Thu: 1pm to 11pm; Fri-Sat: 2pm to 12pm; Sun: 1pm to 11.30pm

pizzaMitica.address: Carrer Major de Sarrià, 78, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, 08017 Barcelona
pizzaMitica.description:
This is a take-away only pizza place in Sarria, selling mini round pizzas with soft dough. They also sell delicious panzarotti, filled with mozzarella and tomatoes.

Prices are not the cheapest, but the quality is good. The place is run by Italians.

This is a decent place to come if you are already in the area and have the munchies, but might not be somewhere you travel halfway across the city for.
pizzaMitica.name: Pizza Mitica

pizzaNatura.address: Carrer de Pau Claris, 153, Eixample, 08009 Barcelona, Spain
pizzaNatura.description: This is a very good gluten-free pizza restaurant - friendly staff, tasty toppings and a great atmosphere. The base is thin and crisp, and almost tortilla-like, which might not be to everyone’s taste, but the flavours really back a punch. Many of the topics are traditionally Italian, but there are also a few options that allow you to venture into more exotic realms, such as the barbecue chicken one. The pizzas are made with quinoa flour. Desserts are worth trying, too, such as the pistachio cheesecake.
pizzaNatura.name: Pizza Natura
pizzaNatura.openingHours: Mon-Thu: 1pm to 5pm & 7.30pm to 11.30pm; Fri-Sat: 1pm to 12am; Sun: 1pm to 11.30pm

pizzadAutore.description:
Come here for some good sliced pizza.

The only downside is that choices become limited about an hour before closing. The décor is simple, and there are only a few tables, so most people take the pizza to go.

Still, a solid choice for a quick and satisfying meal.
pizzadAutore.name: Pizza d’Autore

pummarola.address: Rda. de Sant Pau, 59, Eixample, 08015 Barcelona
pummarola.description:
This is an authentic and friendly traditional Neapolitan pizzeria in the Sant Antoni neighbourhood of the city.

Prices are extremely reasonable and opening hours are very convenient (non-stop from early afternoon to midnight throughout the week, slightly later at weekends).

The restaurant also serves panuozzi, a typical delicious panini from the Campania region of Italy.

Pizzas are all traditional, as are the desserts that they serve.

Simple decor with a few seats outside.
pummarola.name: Pummarola

rasoiGhar.address: Carrer de la Reina Cristina, 10, Bajo, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona
rasoiGhar.description:
This is a fabulous Indian restaurant, with authentic dishes that are positively popping with flavour.

The dishes aren’t terribly well presented, served in fairly nondescript bowls with little in the way of garnish, but this is but a minor quibble when the aromas, taste and service is so good.

The place is pretty big, consisting of two generously-proportioned rooms and an outside veranda. The place is in a prime location, right next to the waterfront, and so nearly always busy and noisy, no matter the time of day or night.

Food is prepared and served very quickly. The waiters are friendly and many speak decent English.

The place is brightly lit and the table cloths are pristinely white. It would be nice if the place had a little bit more Indian flare (beyond the elephants on the doors and the Indian waiters obviously).

At one end of the restaurant there are a few tables partially concealed within separate alcoves, affording groups a bit more privacy and seclusion should they so desire.

There is another branch of this restaurant in Eixample, too.
rasoiGhar.name: Rasoi Ghar

spaccanapoli.address: Carrer del Rec Comtal, 6, Ciutat Vella, 08003 Barcelona
spaccanapoli.description:
This is a truly Neapolitan pizzeria. You can tell the moment that you walk in the place – from the Maradona and Troisi pictures on the walls to the warm friendliness of the staff. Pizzas are not only really good but also extremely reasonably priced.

You will find mostly classic and authentic Neapolitans pizzas here. The frittatina and crocche antipasti are delicious and authentic, too. The restaurant has a large selection of classic Neapolitan desserts, such as tiramisu (you can get a traditional one, but also a delicious pistachio version and one made with pan di stelle), babá au rhum, pastiera and delizia al limone.

There is one caveat to this entry, however. A few years ago, the quality was better. It has dipped slightly and we’re not sure why. Disappointingly the pistachio tiramisu, which was the star of desserts, is one of the dishes that has also lost its shine.
spaccanapoli.name: Spaccanapoli

sushiHouse.address: Carrer de Rocafort, 117, L'Eixample, 08015 Barcelona, Spain
sushiHouse.description:
This is a great little sushi takeaway spot - extremely fresh and very tasty.

Although this is takeaway only, there are some public tables next to a small green area that you can sit at just outside.

The staff are friendly and service is reasonably fast, outside of peak times at least. If you don´t want to wait, you can call them to prepare the sushi in advance, and then just pick up.

The price-to-quality ratio is very good.

The menu has all the classic sushi that you might expect from such a place – nigiri, maki, California rolls. They serve mochi, too.
sushiHouse.name: Sushi House

tapeoGraciaIBarcelona.description: This is a cosy tapas bar in the heart of Gracia offering some great traditional Catalan cooking. The honey ribs are excellent and they offer a very good bomba de Barcelona. The staff are very attentive. When City Trail researchers visited, an English couple popped into the bar especially to complement one member of staff. The place is almost always busy and lively, meaning that if you come in on your own you may be asked to sit at the bar – which is no bad thing as you can then see some of the food getting prepared. If you plan to come during peak dining hours, it’s a good idea to reserve in advance. Unusually the restaurant doesn’t close between lunch and dinner, so you could try to come during a quieter period if you prefer.
tapeoGraciaIBarcelona.name: Tapeo Gracia I Barcelona

teresaCarles.address: Carrer de Jovellanos, 2, Ciutat Vella, 08001 Barcelona
teresaCarles.description:
If you’re looking for great-tasting vegetarian and vegan food, this restaurant should definitely be at the top of your list.

The dishes are excellent: creative, nicely presented and guaranteed to get your taste buds tingling. Prices are extremely reasonable, too.

It is difficult to recommend one single dish ahead of any others, since they are all very good, but their Catalan cannelloni is definitely worth sampling.

Portions are generous and you certainly won’t be leaving here hungry. Service is also superb, and the waiters offer very good advice about what to order.

Perhaps the only downside to the place is that at lunchtime the restaurant offers a severely cut-back menu, which means that you can only choose a few items from each course. While this makes a bit of sense for some of the dishes that are prepared to order, the exclusion of some of the dishes (for example, ice-cream) from the lunchtime menu feels a bit baffling.

The restaurant also offers a lunchtime set menu, which changes every day, although the dishes on this are often less interesting than those you get when ordering à la carte.

The restaurant is quite spacious for Barcelona standards.
teresaCarles.name: Teresa Carles

trafalgarPizzaClub.description:
While the name doesn’t hold the promise of good authentic Italian dining, the pizza-makers are from Naples and the pizzas they prepare are therefore delicious.

The pizzas are fairly classical, albeit with a local twist.

The restaurant is centrally located, near Urquinaona, and very spacious. The restaurant's opening times are extremely convenient, too, and they remain open at times when other pizzerias are closed.

The place offers fast wi-fi that customers can freely use.
trafalgarPizzaClub.name: Trafalgar Pizza Club
trafalgarPizzaClub.openingHours: Mon-Wed: 1pm to 1am; Thu: 1pm to 2am; Sat-Sun: 1pm to 3am

badalona.description: Badalona is a vibrant coastal city in Catalonia, Spain, situated just northeast of Barcelona along the Mediterranean Sea
badalona.highlights:
Known for its beautiful beaches, rich history, and growing urban development, 
Badalona offers a mix of traditional Catalan culture and modern city life
badalona.name: Badalona

subAreas.description: It is a sub area of the place
subAreas.name: Gorg

barceloneta.description:
Consider this area if you want to be close to Barcelona’s beach. Here you will also find the old port (good for catching tourist boats that show you a bit of Barcelona from the water), the city’s aquarium and the cable car that whisks visitors up to Montjuic.

You will find plenty of nightlife spots here, too, such as Opium, Pacha, and Shôko. Lively music often takes place at the restaurants on the beach.
barceloneta.highlights: Barceloneta is a lively seaside neighborhood in Barcelona known for its beaches, seafood restaurants, and old fishing village charm
barceloneta.name: Barceloneta

eixample.description: Eixample is a large district with a well-deserved reputation for being one of the safest in Barcelona. It has plenty of wide streets with good lighting, a mix of residential and commercial neighbourhoods and quite a few tourist spots to visit. Eixample is well-known for its modernist architecture and several iconic landmarks, Sagrada Família probably being the most famous. Since the area is so large, how close you are to the centre and to tourist attractions depends a bit on where you stay. The closest metro stops to the centre are Urquinaona, Passeig deGracia, Universitat and Diagonal. Sagrada Familia, on the other hand, is at the other end of Eixample, and a good 30-minute walk from the old town area. The area is well connected with five metro lines (L1 through to L5) passing through it.
eixample.highlights:
One of Barcelona's safer areas, Luxury designer stores, Plenty of restaurants but quite touristy, 
Modernist architecture, Walking distance from key historical sites, Rent and hotels a bit on the pricey side, 
Popular for street events - 
means good proximity but also chaos
eixample.name: Eixample

subAreas.description: This is one of the most beautiful streets in Barcelona, full of iconic modernist buildings, such as Casa Batlló, Casa Amatller, Casa Lleó Morera and Casa Milà. There are plenty of luxury shopping spots in the area, too. This is a prime location in which meany visitors choose to stay, but it’s not the cheapest. You will find many luxury and boutique hotels here, all with correspondingly high price tags. The area is usually full of people. However, since the boulevard is fairly large, it doesn’t feel quite as crowded as the streets of the old town. Plaça de Catalunya (where the old town begins) is a seven-minute walk from here.  Five minutes away you will find the Egyptian Museum. This area lacks decent restaurants, supermarkets and cafés – but these you will find on some of the streets that run parallel. Many of the shops in this area are closed on Sundays, although the more luxury ones are likely to be open.
subAreas.name: Passeig de Gràcia (L2 - Purple Line; L3 - Green Line; L4 - Yellow Line)

subAreas.description: This area is a short walking distance from the city centre and many key tourist attractions, including some of Barcelona’s most famous modernist buildings and plenty of museums. The area has a range of hotels to match different budges, and there are plenty of restaurants and supermarkets nearby. The Airport Express passes through here, making travelling to and from the airport fairly convenient.  The area is a 25-minute walk from the beach.
subAreas.name: Urquinaona/Universitat (L1 - Red Line)

subAreas.description: This is a less touristic area than many other neighbourhoods in Eixample, with hotels and hostels that are generally more affordable. There are plenty of supermarkets and restaurants here. The area is close to the Sant Antoni food market and a 20-minute walk from Boqueria Market. Plaça d'Espanya is nearby.
subAreas.name: Urgell/Rocafort (L1 - Red Line)

subAreas.description: This is a more residential area. There are a few luxury hotels in the area, but most are in the medium price range. There are plenty of eating options here as well. Many of Barcelona’s main tourist attractions are not far away: Arc de Triomf (seven minutes), Parc de la Ciutadella (10 minutes), Barcelona Zoo (two minutes), Palau Macaya (five minutes), La Sagrada Família (15 minutes).
subAreas.name: Tetuán (L2 - Purple Line)

subAreas.description: This neighbourhood is a little further away from many of Eixample’s main tourist attractions (although only a 10-minute walk from Sagrada Familia). Hotel prices here are slightly cheaper than elsewhere in the district, and the purple metro line affords easy access to many of the main tourist attractions. The easiest tourist attraction to visit on foot is the former bullfighting ring, La Monumental, which is now used for concerts and events. It is famous for its Moorish-style architecture.  Avinguda Diagonal, a five-minute walk away, is a major avenue lined with shops, restaurants, and business centres. A 15-minute walk away is Glòries Tower, a futuristic skyscraper that lights up at night (although this isn’t really an area where you would want to stroll around at night!)  The Encants flea market is also 15 minutes’ away, as is the National Theater of Catalonia, which offers music concerts and cultural performances.
subAreas.name: Monumental (L2 - Purple Line)

subAreas.description: This is a fancy area full of luxury shopping centres, modernist architecture and lively plazas. As you might expect, accommodation here is not cheap. You will find several iconic buildings nearby such as Casa Milà – La Pedrera, Casa de les Punxes and Palau Robert. The area is also only 15-minute walk away from another much-loved part of Barcelona: Gracia.
subAreas.name: Diagonal (L3 - Green Line; L5 - Blue Line)

subAreas.description: This is a quiet yet central area, known for its modernist architecture, charming streets, and local cafés. You can reach many major landmarks in under 15 minutes, including Passeig de Gràcia, Sagrada Família, Parc de la Ciutadella and Arc de Triomf. There are plenty of decent restaurants in the neighbourhood. The area also has a fast metro link to the old town (enter it at the Jaume I metro station). There are good public transport connections to the various beaches of Barcelona, too (or you can walk to these in 20 minutes).
subAreas.name: Girona (L4 - Yellow Line)

subAreas.description: This is a bit outside of the main tourist area, but there are many beautiful art nouveau buildings nearby. Strolling through Carrer d'Enric Granados is a must! This historic Ninot food market is a five-minute walk away. This is great place for experiencing traditional Catalan cuisine. The modernist building Casa Sayrach is five minutes away, while Gaudí’s famous Casa Milà is less than 20 minutes away.
subAreas.name: Hospital Clínic (L5 - Blue Line)

subAreas.description: The main reason you might stay here, of course, is if you want to have Sagrada Família right on your doorstep. But there is also another modernist masterpiece that you shouldn’t miss: the former hospital of Sant Pau, which is a 10-minute walk away.
subAreas.name: Sagrada Família (L5 - Blue Line)

elBorn.description:
This is a great area in which to stay if you want to be in the historical part of the city, surrounded by beautiful churches, plenty of restaurants and cafés. The area is also in walking distance to the beach area of Barceloneta and the old port. Estación de Francia, the railway station that links Barcelona to parts of France, is also located here.

Much of the neighbourhood is pedestrianised. While this improves the safety of the streets, it also means that only official taxis are able to enter many of them. Neither Uber nor Cabify drivers are allowed.

The area is lively at all times, both day and night. Make sure you watch out for pickpockets, especially after sundown and in smaller darker alleys.
elBorn.name: El Born

subAreas.description: This area is located between El Born and the Gothic Quarter. This is a great location in which to be based since it affords easy access several beautiful areas of Barcelona on foot. This metro station is on a main road with both car and bus access.
subAreas.name: Jaume I (L4 - Yellow Line)

subAreas.description: This part of the neighbourhood gives easy access to Barceloneta Beach, which is a 10-minute walk away. It is also near the old port, where visitors can catch a boat to see a bit of Barcelona by sea. There are plenty of restaurants and cafés here (admittedly many of these are fairly touristy, though still might be pleasant for a drink). The smaller streets inside Barceloneta’s former fishing neighbourhood offer a more authentic experience of the city.
subAreas.name: Barceloneta (L4 - Yellow Line)

subAreas.description: Here you will find the zoo and Ciutadella Park, a pleasant place to go for a stroll. There is a lake in the middle with row boats for hire. The area is close to quite a few decent restaurants serving a variety of cuisines (Italian, Mexican, Spanish, Catalan). This is also where you will find Barcelona’s main Chinese neighborhood, good for Chinese food and supermarkets – and of course colourful celebrations during Chinese New Year!
subAreas.name: Arc de Triomf (Red Line - L1)

elRaval.description:
Raval is one of Barcelona’s most densely-populated areas. It has a very high immigrant population, and consequently still has a negative reputation among many locals.
Although not advisable if you are planning to come back late at night, it is becoming an increasingly popular area for those who want to stay close to the centre. More and more decent restaurants are springing up in the area, too.

Do exercise caution if you are going to stay in the area, though, and if you look like a tourist know that you could be an easy target, especially at night. Locals tend not to live here if they can avoid it so you will easily stand out. 

There are several points of interest nearby: the Museum of Contemporary Art, Palau Güell, Rambla del Raval, Sant Pau del Camp (a Romanesque church) and the Boqueria food market.
elRaval.highlights: El Raval is a vibrant, multicultural neighborhood in Barcelona known for its bohemian vibe, street art, and diverse food scene
elRaval.name: El Raval

gracia.description: Consider this area if you want to stay in a slightly less touristy area that has a bit more of a hipster vive – full of restaurants, cafés and cool wine bars. The area is still busy, but it feels more ‘local’ than the true city centre. Of course, it is a bit further away from the main tourist attractions, although direct buses connect to many of them. A popular summer street festival takes place here in August each year.
gracia.highlights: Gràcia is a charming, bohemian neighborhood in Barcelona known for its village-like feel, artistic vibe, and lively plazas
gracia.name: Gràcia

subAreas.description: Fontana is right in the heart of the neighbourhood. It’s only a four-minute walk away from Gaudí’s Casa Vincens. Although the area is 30 minutes from the Gothic Quarter and the attractions nearby, there is a direct metro line that runs there. Parc Guell is a 25-minute walk away.
subAreas.name: Fontana (Green Line - L3)

subAreas.description: This area is a five-minute walk from Casa Padua, and even less to that other modernist jewel Casa Ramos. This is one of the closest metro stations to Park Güell (a 15-minute walk).
subAreas.name: Lesseps – (Green Line – L3)

subAreas.description: Joanic is a well-loved area among locals, with spacious squares all around it, such as Plaça de la Virreina (a five-minute walk), Plaça del Sol (seven minutes) and Carrer de Verdi (10 minutes). This is where you will find the Verdi Cinema, which shows original-language films. This area is also the heart of Gràcia’s nightlife and social life, surrounded by trendy bars and restaurants. A great spot for evening drinks and tapas.
subAreas.name: Joanic – (Yellow Line – L4)

subAreas.description:
This is the area where Eixample and Gràcia intersect, making it a great starting point to explore modernist architecture, cultural sites, and charming neighbourhoods.

There are a number of attractions nearby, including the Gothic-inspired fairytale castle, Casa de les Punxes and Palau Macaya. Gaudí’s famous Casa Milà – La Pedrera is a 10-minute walk away while Sagrada Família is 15 minutes.
subAreas.name: Verdaguer (Blue Line - L5)

subAreas.description: This is a fancy area full of luxury shopping centres, modernist architecture and lively plazas. As you might expect, accommodation here is not cheap. You will several iconic buildings nearby such as Casa Milà – La Pedrera, Casa de les Punxes and Palau Robert. The area is also only 15-minute walk away from another much-love part of Barcelona: Gracia. As you might
subAreas.name: Diagonal (L3 - Green Line; L5 - Blue Line)

lesCorts.description:
This is principally a residential district, but it is become more and more known among tourists because of the number of large hotel chains that have set up here in recent years. Many of these hotels offer great facilities at a lower price when compared to similar hotels in the centre.

This is also a favourite area for the lovers of Barcelona Football Club because of the area’s proximity to the Camp Nou Stadium. This is a popular business district, too.

Although the area is a fair walk from the centre, there is a direct metro to the Gothic Quarter, which can whisk you there in under 15 minutes.

The area is still not too touristy and has a more local feel. Features include a high-end shopping mall (L’Illa Diagonal), Pedralbes Monastery and Reina Elisenda Gardens.
lesCorts.name: Les Corts

pobleSec.description: **Poble-sec** is a vibrant and up-and-coming neighborhood in Barcelona, known for its mix of local charm and lively nightlife. Nestled between **Montjuïc Hill** and **Avinguda del Paral·lel**, it offers a blend of historic theaters, trendy bars, and some of the best tapas streets in the city, like **Carrer de Blai**, famous for its pintxos. With its relaxed atmosphere, cultural venues, and proximity to green spaces, Poble-sec is a favorite for both locals and visitors looking for an authentic Barcelona experience.
pobleSec.highlights: Poble-sec is a lively yet laid-back neighborhood in Barcelona known for its theater scene, tapas bars, and Montjuïc access
pobleSec.name: Poble Sec
